headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is April, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the FLIR Systems Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Financial Results Conference Call. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Wit
componenttext: Good morning. My name is April, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the FLIR Systems Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Financial Results Conference Call. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Wit Davis, Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Security of FLIR Systems. Sir, you may begin.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Before we begin this conference call, I need to remind you that other than statements as to historical facts, the statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities L
componenttext: Good morning, everyone. Before we begin this conference call, I need to remind you that other than statements as to historical facts, the statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and are based on our current expectations. Words such as expects, anticipates, intends, believes, estimates and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify such forward-looking statements. All of these statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to a press release we issued earlier today for a description of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those forecast. Forward-looking statements we make today speak as of today, and we do not undertake any obligation to update any such statements to reflect events or circumstances occurring after today. Let me now turn the call over to Earl Lewis, Chairman and CEO of FLIR Systems. Earl?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Wit, and thank you all for joining us this morning. We are very pleased with our financial performance for all of 2009. FLIR recorded its ninth straight year of record revenue, operating income and earnings per share, and achieved the hig
componenttext: Well, thank you, Wit, and thank you all for joining us this morning. We are very pleased with our financial performance for all of 2009. FLIR recorded its ninth straight year of record revenue, operating income and earnings per share, and achieved the highest operating income margin in our company's history. For all of 2009, revenue increased by 7% to $1.15 billion. We earned $1.45 per share, an increase of 13% compared to '08. We set a record for cash flow from operations, which reached $272 million or 118% of net income. The soft worldwide economy affected our Thermography business the most in 2009, as revenues declined by 13%. But through good expense management, strong gross margins, Thermography operating income rose by 3% for the year. Our Commercial Vision Systems revenue grew by 14% in 2009, and operating profit rose by 32%. These businesses, which, effectively January 1, have been combined into a new Commercial Systems division, are exceptionally well-positioned. And we expect them to post very good growth in 2010.Government Systems had another good year in 2009, with revenue up 15% and operating income up by 22%. We issued our initial outlook for 2010 this morning. For the full year, we currently expect net revenue in the range of $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion and earnings per fully diluted share to be in the range of $1.48 to $1.53. Good growth from Commercial Systems with stabilizing worldwide demand, continued growth in Asia and the impact of numerous new product introductions support our 2009 view. Government Systems, which has grown at a compound rate of 36% for the past three years, will slow in 2010 due largely to the anticipated decline in deliveries of the BETTS-C program and its related programs. However, we expect the core Government Systems business to again perform well in 2010. With that, we'll have each of the company's Presidents talk, beginning with Arne Almerfors. Thank you, Arne.[p id="327425" name="Arne Almerfors" /> Thank you, Earl. Thermography revenue in Q4 was $84.8 million, a decrease of 4% from the fourth quarter of 2008, up 21% from the second quarter, reflecting stabilizing demand, as well as normal seasonal pattern. For all of 2009, revenue was $285.5 million, a decrease of 13% from 2008. Revenue in both the U.S. and Europe were down during 2009, reflecting the impact of the global recession. Revenue in the U.S. increased 5% in the fourth quarter due to growth in the High Volume segment market. Asia-Pacific was the bright spot during the year, as revenue grew over 75%. As a result of our month to year infrastructure investment, Asia-Pacific had healthy growth during the year, particularly in China, Japan and Korea. Thermography operating margin in Q4 was 27%, up from 26% last year due to improved gross margins and cost controls. Q4 operating margin was the highest in two years. And despite lower revenue, operating income of $23.3 million was up 3% over 2008, highlighting our ability to manage the business effectively in a difficult economic environment.For the market segment perspective, the Building market continue to do well in the fourth quarter and represents about 30% of revenue. The Building market has been particularly strong in the U.S. and Europe where government regulations and incentives have helped drive demand. The Electrical & Mechanical market holds about 30% of revenue was slow in the fourth quarter, reflecting continued depressed capital spending activity in the U.S. and Europe. The Electrical & Mechanical market is experiencing growth in Asia-Pacific, as infrastructure development drives demand. In addition, we experienced strong demand for cameras used to detect elevated body temperature in an effort to contain swine flu, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. In the High Volume segment, we recently reduced the street price of our low-cost i5 camera to rent to $1,195 to further stimulate price elastic demand. We also introduced the i7 camera, a higher resolution variant of the same platform at the $2,995 price point. These changes resulted in a year-over-year increase in units of 80%. We expect continued growth in this segment as the economy improves and distribution expands. And I will now turn the call over to Andrew Teich, President of our newly-formed Commercial System division.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Arne. I'm excited about the combination of Thermography and Commercial Vision Systems divisions. There are many similarities between the two businesses, which can be leveraged to create value for FLIR. Both are pursuing commercial customers, both
componenttext: Thanks, Arne. I'm excited about the combination of Thermography and Commercial Vision Systems divisions. There are many similarities between the two businesses, which can be leveraged to create value for FLIR. Both are pursuing commercial customers, both are exploiting the price elasticity of the market, with lower cost uncooled products and both utilize a third-party distribution model in their go-to-market strategy. I look forward to uniting the two divisions and building on our global leadership position in the commercial infrared market.Turning to CVS, the division had a terrific fourth quarter. Revenue was $57 million, an increase of 34% compared to the fourth quarter a year ago and the fastest growth rate in nearly two years. Revenue for the full year of 2009 was $206.3 million, an increase of 14% over the prior year. Backlog increased $10 million during the quarter to $103 million due to strong orders in U.S. course in components and security and surveillance markets. Operating income for Q4 was $13 million, up 61% from the prior year and the second highest in CVS history. Operating margins were 23%, up four percentage points from the prior year due primarily to leveraging of operating costs. Operating income for all of 2009 was $49.3 million, an increase of 32% over the prior year.Demand in the security and surveillance market was excellent around the world, as worldwide orders were up over 3x from the third quarter. Orders for short-range cameras were up significantly, as we trend towards more private industry funding. While we will continue to target large-order programs through our network of integrators, the foundation of our Security business is rapidly moving towards our higher volume, lower priced, uncooled short and mid-range system. Bookings in the fourth quarter were particularly strong in the nuclear power industry, where our new Nuclear Regulatory Commission regulations require a 24/7 surveillance by April 2010. In addition, the new H-Series Hand-Held Thermal Imager gained immediate acceptance and contributed to the growth. In the maritime market, orders were flat with the prior year, as strong growth in the U.S. was offset by a decrease in Europe. Unit volumes doubled in the U.S. as the new First Mate Handheld Camera drove demand. For the year, worldwide orders were up 20%, reflecting healthy demand for a compelling new product segment in an otherwise soft market. We see the Maritime business as having great promise for the future, and we'll continue to focus on expanding distribution and working to establish a position in the maritime electronics industry. To that end, we recently added West Marine to our distribution network. West Marine is the largest nationwide mass retailer of maritime electronics products. They have 340 stores and two major catalogs. We believe West Marine channel will be increasingly important as we work to become a major player in the marine electronics industry. Demand in our Course and Component segment was up over 25% from the fourth quarter of the prior year. Orders were strong across our broad OEM customer base and included growth in a variety of commercial and military applications. Even the Auto segment, which has been slow for most of the year, grew nicely during the fourth quarter. With the addition of the Audi A8 and the Rolls Royce Ghost vehicles, we expect higher volumes for our NV2 core, resulting in lower component costs for our uncooled detectors, which support the cost target goals of products across FLIR. In late December, we announced the acquisition of Directed Perception, a leading provider of pan-tilt motion control systems for our commercial and military market. The acquisition enhances and differentiates our pan-tilt zoom camera systems for both commercial and military markets through lower costs, improve functionality and ease-of-use. We have renamed Directed Perception FLIR Motion Control Systems, and I'm delighted to work welcome their talented employees to our team. Looking to 2010, we see strong performance for the combined Commercial Systems business, driven by a stabilizing economy, a refreshed product line in many markets and the leverage efforts of our newly combined, highly capable team. That concludes my comments. Let me now turn the call over to Bill Sundermeier, President of the Government Systems division.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andy. 2009 was another outstanding year for Government Systems. We increased revenue 15% to a record $655 million, increased operating income by 22% to a record $286 million and achieved operating margins of 44%. Backlog declined 22% during 200
componenttext: Thank you, Andy. 2009 was another outstanding year for Government Systems. We increased revenue 15% to a record $655 million, increased operating income by 22% to a record $286 million and achieved operating margins of 44%. Backlog declined 22% during 2009 to $433 million at year-end due to the high shipments for the BETTS-C programs during the year. Excluding the impact of the BETTS-C programs, net orders increased modestly in 2009, led by a strong order growth internationally. For the fourth quarter, revenue was $169.7 million, a decrease of 1% from the prior year. Q4 operating income of $68.8 million was down 7%, primarily due to revenue mix and increases in R&D and the marketing activities year-over-year. Operating margins of 41% remain very strong in the quarter. Q4 order activity was slower in the U.S. as anticipated, with the late approval of government budgets. International orders continue to grow, however, with more than half of the orders received from overseas customers.With the recent release of the 2010 OCONUS [outside the continental United States] supplemental, the fiscal year 2011 U.S. Defense budget proposal and the Quadrennial Defense Review, we believe EO/IR capabilities will continue to be a priority. And Secretary Gates briefed in on the budget, he highlighted the need to expand both intelligent surveillance and reconnaissance capability and special operations capability, both areas were FLIR has been a key supplier. In addition to U.S. defense requirements, we also believe there's a growing opportunity with the Department of Homeland Security. FLIR has historically been a major supplier to both Customs and Border Protection and the Coast Guard. With a budget request of $56 billion, an increase of over 20% from the prior year, we believe we will see more procurement activity from DHS going forward. In the force protection area, the effort to transition the RAID portion of BETTS-C into an army program of record continues, and we now expect the effort to be completed in time for the fiscal year 2012 budget cycle. The Marines are also running a separate process to transition their GBOSS program to a program of record status, which we believe will also coincide with this fiscal year 2012 budget. There may be opportunities with the Army and the Marines to provide force protection systems prior to the completion of the program of record process, but any orders are difficult to predict at this time. They are having an ongoing dialogue with both the Army and the Marines and look forward to building our long-term relationship. In addition to force protection, another key area of growth for Government Systems is in the handheld and fixed based surveillance system. Over the past several years, we have successfully leveraged our spiral development and vertical integration capabilities to develop an attractively priced line of handheld and fixed based systems that are gaining favor with the worldwide military community. The recent acquisition of OmniTech will further enhance our capabilities in this area. Looking at 2010, we believe Government Systems revenue will be flat to slightly up during the year based on the healthy level of beginning backlog and the current factored order forecast for the year. When the planning for the Afghanistan surge is complete, we expect U.S. DoD procurement activities to improve over the year. We also expect continued growth in our international markets. Operating margins will likely decline a few points as product mix changes, and we invest to support our customer and product expansion plans. We remain very bullish on the long-term prospects for infrared systems in military applications and are excited about 2010 and beyond. That concludes my comments. Let me turn the call back over to Earl.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Bill. Before we hear from Steve, I want to discuss our financial results in detail. I want to comment on our recent management changes. As we announced in December, Arne, President of our Thermography division is going to retire effective Ju
componenttext: Well, thanks, Bill. Before we hear from Steve, I want to discuss our financial results in detail. I want to comment on our recent management changes. As we announced in December, Arne, President of our Thermography division is going to retire effective June 1. And we have consequently consolidated Thermography and CVS into one new commercial division lead by Andy Teich. This is a tremendous opportunity for us to bring together two businesses that are essentially headed in the exact same direction. I'm very excited about the prospects for this new division. I want to also recognize the enormous contributions Arne has made to FLIR. For more than a decade, he has been a very critical part of our success. And he has left us with a tremendously healthy and well-positioned business. Thank you, Arne, and best wishes from us all. We also announced today that Steve Bailey, our Chief Financial Officer since 2000 intends to retire effectively June 1. Steve will be replaced by Tony Trunzo, who's currently Head of our Corporate Strategy. This transition has been very well-planned, and I am confident it will go smoothly. And with that, Steve, can you update us on the financials for 2009?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Earl. Revenue for the fourth quarter 2009 totaled $311.6 million, an increase of 3% from the same quarter last year. Revenue from Government Systems amounted to $169.7 million, a 1% decrease as compared to fourth quarter of 2008. Revenue from o
componenttext: Thank you, Earl. Revenue for the fourth quarter 2009 totaled $311.6 million, an increase of 3% from the same quarter last year. Revenue from Government Systems amounted to $169.7 million, a 1% decrease as compared to fourth quarter of 2008. Revenue from our Commercial Vision Systems division of $57 million, increased 34% as compared to Q4 of 2008. And Thermography revenue of $84.8 million was a decrease of 4% over the fourth quarter of 2008. Our international revenues for the quarter were 44% of total revenue, while revenues from U.S. government sales accounted for 38% of the totality of revenue during the period.For 2009, revenue totaled $1,147,000,000, an increase to 7% as compared to 2008. For the year, Government System's revenue of $655.3 million was an increase of 15%. Thermography revenue of $285.5 million was a decrease of 13% and revenues from Commercial Vision Systems of $206.3 million represents an increase of 14% percent as compared to 2008. For 2009, international revenues were 41% of our total revenues, while revenues in U.S. government sales accounted for 43%.We closed the year with a backlog of $563 million, a 7% decline during the quarter. Our backlog has decreased 15% or $100 million over backlog at year-end 2008. At year-end, division backlog amounted to Government Systems of $433 million, a decrease of 22% over 2008; Thermography backlog was $27 million, a 42% increase over last year; while Commercial Vision Systems backlog of $103 million was an increase of 13%.Gross margins for the fourth quarter were 56.5% of revenue as compared to 57.4% of revenue for the same quarter last year. The decrease in average gross margin during the quarter is primarily due to the shift of product mix in both Government Systems and Commercial Vision Systems. For the year, gross margins were 57.4% as compared to 56.3% in 2008, with margin improvement related to production and manufacturing efficiencies. Research and development expense of $24.4 million or 7.8% of revenue for the quarter as compared to $21.7 million or 7.2% of revenue for the fourth quarter 2008. For the year, the company has incurred research and development expense of $91.3 million or 8% of revenue, as compared to $90 million or 8.4% of revenue during 2008.Selling, general and administrative expense for the quarter and the year of $61.7 million and $219.9 million, respectively, were constant at 19.8% and 19.2% of revenue for the period. Earnings from operations for the fourth quarter totaled $89.9 million or 28.9% of revenue as compared to $88.1 million or 29.1% of revenue for the fourth quarter 2008. Quarterly earnings from operations as provided by the operating divisions were $68.8 million from Government Systems, a 7% decrease; $13 million from Commercial Vision Systems, a 61% increase; and $23.3 million from Thermography, a 3% increase as compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. From operations, corporate expenses were $15.2 million, a 9% decrease as compared to the fourth quarter of 2008. For 2009 full year, earnings from operations were $347.3 million or 30.3% of revenue, an increase of $62.8 million or 22% over 2008. For the year, earnings from operations were Government Systems of $286.4 million, a 22% increase; Commercial Vision Systems $49.3 million, a 32% increase; and Thermography, $72.9 million, an increase of 3%; with corporate operating expense of $61.3 million, an increase of 7%.Interest expense for the quarter and the year totaled $1.1 million and $6.9 million, respectively and is primarily relates to the interest cost and amortization transaction costs for our convertible notes. During the quarter, the company earned $1.7 million of other income from a number of sources, including $200,000 of currency gains, $400,000 of interest income and $1.1 million of other investment income as compared to $11.6 million of quarterly income in 2008, which included $10.2 million of currency gains during that period of 2008. For the full year 2009, other expenses amounted to a nominal $12,000 as currency losses of $3.9 million were offset with interest income of $1.7 million and other investment income of $2.1 million. This compared to 2008 other income of $20.2 million, which included currency gains of $12.9 million and interest income of $7.4 million. Based on the mix of foreign and domestic income for the full year, the effective tax rate for the quarter was approximately 33.4% and 32.4% for the full year. The increase in the annual rate over the 30.8% reported in 2008 was primarily due to the change in geographic mix of earnings and higher state tax rules.For the fourth quarter, net earnings of $60.3 million or $0.38 per diluted share, as compared to earnings of $65 million or $0.41 per diluted share for the same quarter 2008. For full 2009, net earnings were $230.2 million or $1.45 per diluted share and the increase over 2008 net earnings of $200.9 million or $1.28 per diluted share. We finished the year with cash on hand of $422 million as compared to Q3 quarter-ending cash balance of $403.3 million and a year-end 2008 cash balance of $289.4 million. During the fourth quarter, the cash increase of $18.7 million was primarily due to cash provided from operating activities of $72.3 million, cash generated from stock compensation programs of $12.2 million and cash provided by other investing activities of $4.2 million, partially offset by business acquisitions of $60.4 million, capital expenditures of $7.4 million and the negative impact of cash on the exchange rates of $2.4 million. For the year, we had an increase in cash of $132.6 million. For 2009, we generated cash from operations of $271.8 million, cash from stock compensation programs of $31.2 million and from other investment of $7.7 million. Partially offsetting these amounts were cash used of $73.6 million for acquisitions, $73.2 million used for repurchase of common stock, capital expenditures of $41.9 million and repayment of debt of approximately $2 million, and the positive impact of currency exchange rates increased cash by $12.1 million. This concludes the summary for fourth quarter and full year fiscal results. Earl, I'll turn the call back to you.

We will be preparing it over that period of time because it's actually empty, but being leased by I think it's DuPont. And they'll be paying us -- we will gradually move into that building and move out of the four different buildings that we occupy today.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And just regarding the Thermography segment, the high performance market has been down all year as you expected, but when do you expect to see some traction there? Is it all macro-related or is there something else going on such as kind of cannibalization
componenttext: And just regarding the Thermography segment, the high performance market has been down all year as you expected, but when do you expect to see some traction there? Is it all macro-related or is there something else going on such as kind of cannibalization?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not cannibalization. I think it's absolute macro-related. And if you plot the delta in our growth rates quarter-to-quarter, this quarter was by far the -- we were down 4% from a year ago. That's a significant change. So the ramp is clearly in the righ
componenttext: No, not cannibalization. I think it's absolute macro-related. And if you plot the delta in our growth rates quarter-to-quarter, this quarter was by far the -- we were down 4% from a year ago. That's a significant change. So the ramp is clearly in the right direction here. And that's been kind of across the board now. So we look to that business to be pretty good next year. First of all, it's low comparison and second, it does appear that at least in the beginning of the year so far, Thermography is rebounding.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And just one quick final one and just about cash deployment, what are your thoughts about for 2010? You mentioned that you've been selective acquisitions and in the past, it seems like you've devoted about 40% of your free cash flow to acquisitions and th
componenttext: And just one quick final one and just about cash deployment, what are your thoughts about for 2010? You mentioned that you've been selective acquisitions and in the past, it seems like you've devoted about 40% of your free cash flow to acquisitions and the balance for buybacks and other investments, how do we think about for 2010?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think there's anything wrong with the formula that we've been kind of working on in the past. So I would suspect in terms of, Peter, your forecasting, I think that's probably as good a forecast as I could think of right now. But as you know,
componenttext: Well, I don't think there's anything wrong with the formula that we've been kind of working on in the past. So I would suspect in terms of, Peter, your forecasting, I think that's probably as good a forecast as I could think of right now. But as you know, acquisitions can be large, and they can be small. And they can kind of come or they could kind of go, and they're very, very hard to predict. But in the general model, I guess I'd use what we've done historically.

componenttext: First off, on BETTS-C, I understand that maybe you don't have perfect visibility on either of that or what the Marine Corps is doing, but the Army is asking for, I guess, close to $500 million in funding in the government fiscal '11 budget for BETTS-C. And the I think it's going to ask for something like $200 million in the pending Afghanistan supplemental appropriations. I mean, do you have a sense of what kind of content there might be and maybe if you can talk about the RAID component of that and any other content you might have as well?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll let Bill expound on this. And we do have some visibility, and we are not forecasting a big effect of any of that on this year. But with that, Bill, why don't you maybe go into some of the detail that we do know?
componenttext: Yes, we'll let Bill expound on this. And we do have some visibility, and we are not forecasting a big effect of any of that on this year. But with that, Bill, why don't you maybe go into some of the detail that we do know?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tim. There's actually $302 million in the 2010 OCONO (sic) [OCONUS] supplemental that played in for BETTS-C. We don't have very good resolution into that as of yet. That should start flowing after Memorial Day, so I don't see any near-term spending
componenttext: Sure, Tim. There's actually $302 million in the 2010 OCONO (sic) [OCONUS] supplemental that played in for BETTS-C. We don't have very good resolution into that as of yet. That should start flowing after Memorial Day, so I don't see any near-term spending from that. But that is something that let's say conservatively optimistic about to provide some opportunities for us. There's also you mentioned $486 million in the fiscal year 2011 budget, and I have the JBook in front of me here. There's $24.4 million in for Cerberus, which we are a player in. Now realize that there are four components to BETTS-C, which we play and major player in two of those, the tall RAID towers and the Cerberus programs. So there's some potential there. The actual RAID line item is empty as it was in fiscal year '09. But some new line items have come on from BETTS-C system reset at $72.5 million and initial spares at $38.7 million. So we're trying to gain more visibility into the portions of that, that might be coming our way for both for RAID replacements, as well as Cerberus systems. But don't have further detail and of course, that's FY '11 funding, and it won't flow until Q4 this year starting in October. So we remain conservatively optimistic about what is our potential for this year when it comes to the RAID program.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And can you lay out your expectations in I guess as much detail as you can for RAID and similar programs in 2010. Is it below $50 million and anything you get in addition to that is incremental to guidance, and then maybe if you could just talk about the
componenttext: And can you lay out your expectations in I guess as much detail as you can for RAID and similar programs in 2010. Is it below $50 million and anything you get in addition to that is incremental to guidance, and then maybe if you could just talk about the international bookings you've been seeing, which have been I think exceptionally strong and what you see going forward?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: We wouldn't want to speculate. We really haven't forecasted bookings. The best thing I can say is what I have been saying is we think that there's opportunity there. It might provide upside and really have conservative model this year. On the internationa
componenttext: We wouldn't want to speculate. We really haven't forecasted bookings. The best thing I can say is what I have been saying is we think that there's opportunity there. It might provide upside and really have conservative model this year. On the international side, we have seen a great year in 2010 and think that, that can repeat here in 2011, our products. As we continue to push over internationally, we're growing that organization and as we bring on our uncooled products, I think we could get further traction internationally. And also, one of the things that was mentioned in the QDR, the Quadrennial Review is certainly the support of our foreign partners. And we see a lot of  FMS activity going on for our partners who are -- and our allies who are helping us out in the Middle East and continue to see that kind of money flowing and should provide us some great business worth in 2010.

componenttext: And your next question comes from Jonathan Ho. [William Blair & Co.]

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a couple of quick questions. First, with regard to the late signing of the Defense budget, are you seeing a resumption in the contract activity now that it's been signed, and what are some of the sort of potential opportunities that are
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a couple of quick questions. First, with regard to the late signing of the Defense budget, are you seeing a resumption in the contract activity now that it's been signed, and what are some of the sort of potential opportunities that are in the budget that you can point to as maybe opportunities?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in the budget, as it's been moving forward, we to continue to see funding towards our core programs with NTPs [nanotransposon particles] [ph] and SOCOM funding and certainly, ISR funding that's happening. So those are very nice area that continue to
componenttext: Well, in the budget, as it's been moving forward, we to continue to see funding towards our core programs with NTPs [nanotransposon particles] [ph] and SOCOM funding and certainly, ISR funding that's happening. So those are very nice area that continue to be strong growth potential for us. Really, the major thing that we're focused on is the implementation of the Afghanistan surge. And that gets better defined over the next few months where that would provide more insight to what kind of things are going to be needing over there from a special forces, as well as the force protection component. So a lot of things -- business coming our way, that's normal. But really, this Afghan surge and its definition is paramount for us to learn in the next couple of months.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And can you talk a little bit about maybe expectations for backlogs or I guess in terms of the trends for this year, and what do you expect to maybe end the year flat in terms of the backlog or whether you take it, can sustain at current levels?
componenttext: And can you talk a little bit about maybe expectations for backlogs or I guess in terms of the trends for this year, and what do you expect to maybe end the year flat in terms of the backlog or whether you take it, can sustain at current levels?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Don't speculate on that area. We've certainly -- that's going to be bookings-dependent on this year, and hope to have a good solid bookings plan. And we have managed this business, we've had the luxury for the last couple of years to really have a nice ba
componenttext: Don't speculate on that area. We've certainly -- that's going to be bookings-dependent on this year, and hope to have a good solid bookings plan. And we have managed this business, we've had the luxury for the last couple of years to really have a nice backlog and have the factory full at the beginning of every single quarter. But historically, we have managed it with some portion of book and bill. And we do have a very strong Book and Bill business. So even if backlog does decline, we have great potential to fill it in every quarter.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick question for Andy, in terms of maybe some potential opportunities for cost savings in the Commercial business as you look forward, can you maybe talk a little bit about what your plans are there?
componenttext: And just a quick question for Andy, in terms of maybe some potential opportunities for cost savings in the Commercial business as you look forward, can you maybe talk a little bit about what your plans are there?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Jonathan, I think it's all about volume in the Uncooled business across the board as we mentioned in the prepared comments. We're seeing increased volumes for uncooled products. The big driver there is automotive, with two new OEMs onboard. Our Q4 b
componenttext: Well, Jonathan, I think it's all about volume in the Uncooled business across the board as we mentioned in the prepared comments. We're seeing increased volumes for uncooled products. The big driver there is automotive, with two new OEMs onboard. Our Q4 bookings in the automotive sector were almost 2x, what they were historically, which is what we'd expect to see kind in a couple of new OEMs onboard. So that will pull our detector costs down across the board. We're also taking some actions to consolidate some of the manufacturing activities between CVS and Thermography, most notably in the area of lenses. For example, Arne makes all of his own lenses. And right now or up until now, I've bought all my lenses externally for the CVS business, and we'll move those internally. So we'll see a pickup there. As we have done, we'll probably give some of that back to the market to continue to flex the price elasticity. We've seen very good elasticity in both CVS and Thermography business. As Arne mentioned, with the price reduction on i5, very, very good demonstrated price elasticity there. And I'm seeing it in the CVS business on products like First Mate Handheld Thermal Imager at $3,000 that we've got in the maritime market. We're seeing very, very good pickup rates there. So I think that our forecast for the year is actually to have operating income be in line with where it has been historically.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, one quick comment. When you look at all of the different projects that government consistently [ph] is working on, it appears they're very much back end in this year. Some of the larger programs we're bidding and working on, including RAID it ap
componenttext: Jonathan, one quick comment. When you look at all of the different projects that government consistently [ph] is working on, it appears they're very much back end in this year. Some of the larger programs we're bidding and working on, including RAID it appears, we're not going to have good visibility until Q3 or Q4. And that's a bit difficult for us. So to answer your question is as crisply as we would like to, I can't. But we do gain a percent yield. There are some programs that are fairly good-sized in nature that we will conclude hopefully in Q3 and Q4. And I think that our problem this year in some ways is that we don't see a lot on the horizon in the short run in Q1 and Q2. And we see quite a bit in Q3 and Q4, including some RAID activity and others. So that's the basis of our thinking in putting together this budget. It's a plan based on what we know right now about the timing of various events, best we can do.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: I've got a question for Andy, a question for Bill. Starting with Andy, you said that you saw strength globally in the Security and Surveillance segment for CVS. Can you tell us what kind of customers you're selling the solution into like sort of state, yo
componenttext: I've got a question for Andy, a question for Bill. Starting with Andy, you said that you saw strength globally in the Security and Surveillance segment for CVS. Can you tell us what kind of customers you're selling the solution into like sort of state, your government or private? And also, what kind of deal size you're seeing typically and is that changing with time?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: So Paul, I wish I had a more specific answer for you on Security, but it's really is everything. We did see the largest unit volume increase in our uncooled sector. So as we continue to push lower price, short and medium-range, uncooled products into the
componenttext: So Paul, I wish I had a more specific answer for you on Security, but it's really is everything. We did see the largest unit volume increase in our uncooled sector. So as we continue to push lower price, short and medium-range, uncooled products into the market, we're seeing the unit volumes there grow more significantly than we do on the long-range cooled stuff. But that said, we had a strong quarter in the long-range business and in terms of deal size, we know we're seeing everything from $11 million down to sales of $3,000, so they vary. The thing that's growing, I'd say our Border business is continuing along at a pace in which it has historically. If I look at the segment that's really growing, it's industrial users picking up the use of this product. So it's everything from golf courses to information data centers to infrastructure, schools, universities and that piece picked up pretty strongly in Q4 actually. So we're feeling good about that.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well what do you think the common thread is there? Is it growing awareness, better distribution, is there some reason for the pickup?
componenttext: Well what do you think the common thread is there? Is it growing awareness, better distribution, is there some reason for the pickup?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. We basically are pulling on two levers which are price and awareness. And awareness is certainly growing in this market that's helping us and with other players coming into the market, we're partnered with Pelco and there are other big security names
componenttext: Yes. We basically are pulling on two levers which are price and awareness. And awareness is certainly growing in this market that's helping us and with other players coming into the market, we're partnered with Pelco and there are other big security names that are getting into the business with thermal-base products now, so that's driving awareness. And the other issue is the distribution. So we continue quarter after quarter to add to our dealer base and at this point have more than 350 authorized distribution outlets for FLIR security products worldwide.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, there is one other thing. We have significantly increased the size of the product offering. And there's significantly more new products this year than there were last. And I think the combination of all three of those things, the two you mentioned,
componenttext: Paul, there is one other thing. We have significantly increased the size of the product offering. And there's significantly more new products this year than there were last. And I think the combination of all three of those things, the two you mentioned, awareness and the need, if you will, but also we really do have by far the most complete product line in the world for security cameras all the way from very inexpensive to the very expensive. And these can be chained together because nothing -- you have different requirements for different cameras. Some need to see a hundred yards, some need to see a mile.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me turn to Bill. I've got sort of a two-part question. Transition to program of record status, that seems to take a long time doesn't it? Why is it taking so long? And then perhaps more importantly, is it a good thing or a bad thing from an investor p
componenttext: Let me turn to Bill. I've got sort of a two-part question. Transition to program of record status, that seems to take a long time doesn't it? Why is it taking so long? And then perhaps more importantly, is it a good thing or a bad thing from an investor perspective when these products get wrapped in to such a program? Because the way I understand it, as the likelihood of you seeing purchases kind of increases but the visibility into the purchases reduces dramatically because it becomes kind of book and ship type business? Am I wrong?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think on the program of record why does it take so long, I know that we've really been focused on supplying the troops and theater, and that's really been a huge effort for both the Army and the Marine Corps to manage. And now that it has been suc
componenttext: Well, I think on the program of record why does it take so long, I know that we've really been focused on supplying the troops and theater, and that's really been a huge effort for both the Army and the Marine Corps to manage. And now that it has been successful over multiple years, typically that's when something does transition to a program of record. And it was early this last year, it was what portions have been successful of BETTS-C if you will that we do want to carry forward as a program of record, so that was early been sitting down over this last year of finding out what was successful in Iraq, and fair what they did want to carry forward from all the different things that were field-in. So I think that they're on the right track now in scaling these programs down to the products that they did find very useful, and some of the things that -- they looked at it as how mobile some platforms were versus other things like that. So clearly the surge getting things there, finally winning it down to the items that they really want for the long run. Reflecting on the program of record, is it good or bad as an investor. As things get put into the president's budget, very similar to what we're seeing here for the 2011 budget. You have multiple line items and they continue to get flexed up over years in maintenance programs. I think you could get a little bit more visibility into what happens and these programs will be scaled down to be a little bit more specific versus the many different pieces that we'd see there. So there'll be some more insight. And of course as a program of record happens, we'll be more in tune with the program office and add better communications with them on a yearly basis about why they're putting in certain dollars in those budgets. So I think as an investor, it will give us more insight over the long run.

componenttext: Jim, I don't have the numbers handy. But clearly, if you look at FLIR, it's RAID program in 2010 is a hole we got to fill. And it's a hole, it's pretty -- it's big, not an easy hole to fill. And we think we'll do that, with what I would call the normal business of FLIR. That normal business continues to grow and we think high double digits for our commercial businesses and at least I think double digits for Builds business, I don't have it right in front of me without RAID. And I guess my plea to you all that looks at our company is to try to realize there is a bubble that we're going to go through. And we're trying to get through that as best we can.

componenttext: Okay. And then if I may, just a question for Andy. Just as we think about the commercial business in 2010, can you talk a little bit about the pipeline, the new product pipeline and to what extent you see that being a driver to the growth in the business?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim. It's significant for us. Earl mentioned it earlier in the commentary. For example, we on the security sector, we launched 21 new products at as is on the fall last year, and we're seeing very good reception from those products. We launched in ev
componenttext: Yes, Jim. It's significant for us. Earl mentioned it earlier in the commentary. For example, we on the security sector, we launched 21 new products at as is on the fall last year, and we're seeing very good reception from those products. We launched in every single sector that we're in, we launched a new product in 2009. And you'll see us launch fewer new products in 2010 because these things tend to come at more like 18 month cycles. But that said, we're at the Miami Boat Show today launching a new product into the Maritime segment, another variant of the M-series. And we've had very good success with these handheld products that we've launched into the security sector into the maritime sector. And that we were at the Consumer Electronics Show in January launching a handheld product into the outdoorsmen market. So I think all those are going to drive growth. I mean the market likes new products and these are innovative new products, they're at low price points and I think the market's going to respond well to them.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010

componenttext: A reception to that whole line of handheld products has been unbelievable. I mean we had some handheld products before but the new ones have just -- we don't normally share unit volume numbers, but the term order of magnitude is appropriate.

componenttext: If you calculated it, could you provide us with the measure we can use for forecasting for the impact of each 5% shift in the dollar euro exchange rate?

componenttextpreview: We probably could.
componenttext: We probably could.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Whether we would be that accurate in doing it, I don't know. But there's a number of variables including our own mix that would throw that number potentially off. We can take a directional shot at it.
componenttext: Whether we would be that accurate in doing it, I don't know. But there's a number of variables including our own mix that would throw that number potentially off. We can take a directional shot at it.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: I mean there's a couple of things. First of all, it's not just dollar to euro. We've got a variety of currency pairs and dollar kroner is actually the big one because of our manufacturing activities in Sweden. These guys are giving me numbers. I think we'
componenttext: I mean there's a couple of things. First of all, it's not just dollar to euro. We've got a variety of currency pairs and dollar kroner is actually the big one because of our manufacturing activities in Sweden. These guys are giving me numbers. I think we've got a total of like 18 currency pairs that we deal with. Dollar-euro,  kroner-euro, kroner-dollar, sterling-dollar, riyal-dollar, all have measurable effects. So it's not -- in our case, the reason we haven't called it out on a frequent basis is in our case, they tend to balance each other out at the EBIT line. The below the line number has to bounce around a lot. And in Q4 of last year, we had a huge gain because there was enormous volatility in the quarter. We're working more aggressively to try and tame that beast and I think we probably will.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Now on Directed Perception, well it's small. What sort of edge do you think it gives you? How does it impact the build versus buy decision?
componenttext: Now on Directed Perception, well it's small. What sort of edge do you think it gives you? How does it impact the build versus buy decision?

componenttextpreview: It means that we're going to build instead of buy.
componenttext: It means that we're going to build instead of buy.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Are there any pebbles [ph] involved here, anything particularly unusual?
componenttext: Are there any pebbles [ph] involved here, anything particularly unusual?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Well a couple of things there, Steve. An increasing extent, particularly in the security sector when we sell a camera it gets sold on a positioner, and we have been sourcing those positioners from multiple parties. So we've get some that we pull out of Ch
componenttext: Well a couple of things there, Steve. An increasing extent, particularly in the security sector when we sell a camera it gets sold on a positioner, and we have been sourcing those positioners from multiple parties. So we've get some that we pull out of China, we got some we pull out of the U.S., we got some that we pull out of Eastern Europe. And they're different capacities and have different levels of fidelity and speed and so forth. The thing that's nice about Directed Perception and what attracted us to them is that they have a very broad line of products. It's a U.S. company, it's in California here and they cover very small high-fidelity, low-cost pan-tilts all the way up to large very rugged pan-tilts. It will take some time for us to get those products integrated together with our sensors. But ultimately, I think you'll see a very large portion of our Positioning business going through that facility.

componenttext: I'd say pretty much in line with our historical records of margin. The rate program margins are slightly decreasing over time. But in general, as RESET comes our way, we'll sustain our margin.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, Earl, just after some belt-tightening in 2009, it looks like operating expenses are going to be up about 10% or so in 2010. Can you give us sort of what's happening there, where the spend is going in terms of is it more R&D to get some n
componenttext: And then I guess, Earl, just after some belt-tightening in 2009, it looks like operating expenses are going to be up about 10% or so in 2010. Can you give us sort of what's happening there, where the spend is going in terms of is it more R&D to get some new products, are you ramping up staff?

componenttextpreview: Well, we are going to hire. Still a little debatable how much we're going to hire. But our plans are more employees, not less by the end of this year. And in two areas, primarily R&D and sales and marketing, less in G&A.
componenttext: Well, we are going to hire. Still a little debatable how much we're going to hire. But our plans are more employees, not less by the end of this year. And in two areas, primarily R&D and sales and marketing, less in G&A.

componenttext: And then just about -- maybe this one's for Bill, last one here, then I'll jump off. headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And this might be a question for both Bill and Andy, I understand airports and ports are actively beefing up their perimeter security. Is this a market you guys are targeting and would it fall under your government division or commercial?
componenttext: And this might be a question for both Bill and Andy, I understand airports and ports are actively beefing up their perimeter security. Is this a market you guys are targeting and would it fall under your government division or commercial?

componenttextpreview: It falls under commercial. And that's a business that we've serviced through a network of integrators. We are absolutely targeting it aggressively and have seen good results. And I would say if you look around the U.S. today, there's four or five airports
componenttext: It falls under commercial. And that's a business that we've serviced through a network of integrators. We are absolutely targeting it aggressively and have seen good results. And I would say if you look around the U.S. today, there's four or five airports now that have fairly sizable deployments on them and we've got a very large percentage of those are using FLIR products today.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's good market for us clearly than it has been. Infrared makes tremendous sense to those applications, and that's been recognized.
componenttext: I think it's good market for us clearly than it has been. Infrared makes tremendous sense to those applications, and that's been recognized.

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Lewis.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Just -- Bill, if I could follow up from Tim's question earlier in the queue. We had $486 million allocated to BETTS-C. We also see in the fiscal year '10 OCO the addition of a few hundred million for the Afghan surge. What about the portion of the BETTS-C
componenttext: Just -- Bill, if I could follow up from Tim's question earlier in the queue. We had $486 million allocated to BETTS-C. We also see in the fiscal year '10 OCO the addition of a few hundred million for the Afghan surge. What about the portion of the BETTS-C program that's allocated to reset in retrofits? How large is that and has that already been incorporated into the numbers discussed?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: BETTS-C set some RESET with $72.5 million in the 2011 budget and retrofit 59.7. And I really think that, that 59.7 is going to be used for some software upgrade and the inclusion of some integration that's going on with those systems. So kind of looking a
componenttext: BETTS-C set some RESET with $72.5 million in the 2011 budget and retrofit 59.7. And I really think that, that 59.7 is going to be used for some software upgrade and the inclusion of some integration that's going on with those systems. So kind of looking at the RESET portion as -- that RESET portion could be used for anyone of the four or all of the four areas of BETTS-C. But we're looking for more detail there.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: So it is about $130 million. Let me just shift gears here for one second, if we look at the EO/IR market for helicopters alone, have you assessed what you think FLIR's market share of that area is at this time? And what is your outlook for the next 12 to
componenttext: So it is about $130 million. Let me just shift gears here for one second, if we look at the EO/IR market for helicopters alone, have you assessed what you think FLIR's market share of that area is at this time? And what is your outlook for the next 12 to 18 months because helicopters have done significantly better in the budgets than what has been expected? And what's your thought there?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Exactly. And it actually did spell out increasing the helicopter capability in the near term. And haven't calculated what our market share is there but the things that are important, for example, are big increase of Black Hawks. And as we've mentione
componenttext: Yes. Exactly. And it actually did spell out increasing the helicopter capability in the near term. And haven't calculated what our market share is there but the things that are important, for example, are big increase of Black Hawks. And as we've mentioned last year, we even wanted programs for putting our talents on Black Hawk. So that re-invigors that we're going to continue to see orders in the future to put our systems on the Black Hawk helicopters. That part of the business is strong for us and it's great that helicopter's growing. And hope we can try and look at what the total market penetration is on all U.S. and international helicopters. But we have strong international partners with Agusta and Eurocopter and are quite often on those platforms abroad. That will be a strengthening area for us this year.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And so where are we going with this is that is we know where we are in the ground systems with regard to some of the issues on next year's revenue ramp? But don't you feel that the areas like helicopters, other airborne sensors will be able to accelerate
componenttext: And so where are we going with this is that is we know where we are in the ground systems with regard to some of the issues on next year's revenue ramp? But don't you feel that the areas like helicopters, other airborne sensors will be able to accelerate moving into the next 12 to 18 months and set aside some of these revenue shortfalls that we bear witness of, of programs like RAID and BETTS-C? That's what I want to address there.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. You're right, those areas are very strong for us and I do see some growth. And we'll see how fast that growth is to counteract the BETTS-C decline, perhaps and as the budget gets clear, there won't be much of a decline in BETTS-C. But we have to see
componenttext: Sure. You're right, those areas are very strong for us and I do see some growth. And we'll see how fast that growth is to counteract the BETTS-C decline, perhaps and as the budget gets clear, there won't be much of a decline in BETTS-C. But we have to see and we've been very concerned about forecasting.

componenttext: And then just one question for Steve. Steve, should we be assuming about 20 or 25 basis points on cash interest on the P&L right now?

componenttextpreview: That's quite about right.
componenttext: That's quite about right.

componenttext: It's actually Jim Moore in for Michael French. Just given the late passage of fiscal 2010 budget, you guys said that the first quarter, say weak, but it might be less strong than the fourth quarter. Are you expecting a catch up or a faster purchasing, first quarter at all that you could see from the delayed passage in budget?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't necessarily see a catch up in Q1. Maybe it will happen in Q2 but the money is flowing slowly. I really think the poll is revolving around what's going to go on with the definition of surge. So you have a lot of things happening out at one time, th
componenttext: I don't necessarily see a catch up in Q1. Maybe it will happen in Q2 but the money is flowing slowly. I really think the poll is revolving around what's going to go on with the definition of surge. So you have a lot of things happening out at one time, that money flowing in Q2. The 2010 OCO, I don't expect that to flow until more at least that could really -- we wouldn't see that until Q3 is flowing. And of course the 2011 budget that we've been talking about won't fall until end of Q4.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a general comment, a lot of focus in the call on U.S. buying. Q4, better than half of our orders for government were international. And it just doesn't appear to me that in 2010, we're going to see a significant reduction in concern by international
componenttext: Just a general comment, a lot of focus in the call on U.S. buying. Q4, better than half of our orders for government were international. And it just doesn't appear to me that in 2010, we're going to see a significant reduction in concern by international companies. And so I suspect that, that part of our business will see some pretty good growth in this year. And the U.S. government, which seems to be almost harder to project is still open in our mind as to what we expect from them this year.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: And when you look into fill the BETTS-C GAAP you said with growth from your other segments, you guys will be willing break out the assumptions for your BETTS-C in the guidance?
componenttext: And when you look into fill the BETTS-C GAAP you said with growth from your other segments, you guys will be willing break out the assumptions for your BETTS-C in the guidance?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think that's just a path to -- I understand why you're asking, it's a very legitimate question. But I think if we start doing it, we're going to end up doing it for a lot of things and it's probably not going to do any of us any go
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think that's just a path to -- I understand why you're asking, it's a very legitimate question. But I think if we start doing it, we're going to end up doing it for a lot of things and it's probably not going to do any of us any good by the time we're done.

componenttext: And the White House proposed the significant ISR spending increases for the fiscal 2011 budget, where do you guys see opportunities there?

componenttext: As we mentioned and helicopters certainly been pushed up, more programs mentioned, Investor Day, and more ISR in the six-wing aircraft, a little bit more in the UAV capability, and as Tier 2 continues to get defined. So lot's of different opportunities behind our -- and vehicles...

componenttext: Vehicles just keep coming back.

componenttext: And then given this last question here, with your use of cash relating to M&A opportunities for next year, for this year, more properties can become up for sale. Are you guys seeing more financing availability and how do you see that environment?

componenttextpreview: Financing isn't an issue for us. We've got plenty of cash and an unused line of credit.
componenttext: Financing isn't an issue for us. We've got plenty of cash and an unused line of credit.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb-11-2010
componenttextpreview: Number of opportunities, I would suspect there'll be more this year than there were last year. Just thinking out loud here, I think that we'll probably see more.
componenttext: Number of opportunities, I would suspect there'll be more this year than there were last year. Just thinking out loud here, I think that we'll probably see more.
