headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Monica, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the FLIR Systems First 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Wit Davis, Senior Vice Pre
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Monica, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the FLIR Systems First 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. I will now turn the call over to Mr. Wit Davis, Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of FLIR Systems. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Before we begin this conference call, I need to remind you that other than statements of historical facts, the statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Liti
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Before we begin this conference call, I need to remind you that other than statements of historical facts, the statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and are based on our current expectations. Words such as expects, anticipates, intends, believes, estimates and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify such forward-looking statements.
All of these statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to the press release we issued earlier today for a description of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those forecast. The forward-looking statements we make today speak as of today, and we do not undertake any obligation to update any such statements to reflect events or circumstances occurring after today. Let me now turn the call over to Earl Lewis, Chairman and CEO of FLIR Systems. Earl?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Wit, and thank you for joining us this morning. We are very pleased with our performance in the first quarter. We earned $0.35 per share on a 6% increase in revenue to $287 million. Our Commercial business did much better than they did last yea
componenttext:
Thank you, Wit, and thank you for joining us this morning. We are very pleased with our performance in the first quarter. We earned $0.35 per share on a 6% increase in revenue to $287 million. Our Commercial business did much better than they did last year and as planned, the Government Systems revenue was little changed. Gross margins and operating margins improved from Q4 and remain at near-record levels.
Both of our Commercial businesses reported better year-over-year margins in Q1. While Government margins were down slightly from last year but remain very strong. Cash from operations was $82 million and cash balances increased by $40 million during the quarter. Our 12-month backlog at the end of the quarter was $543 million, down approximately 4% and in line with our expectations. With that, I'm going to turn this call over to Andy to discuss Q1 Commercial Systems. Andy?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Earl. The new Commercial Systems division has been together for nearly four months. And we've made significant progress capitalizing on the combination. We are working to streamline the sales and marketing organization, leverage operational synerg
componenttext:
Thanks, Earl. The new Commercial Systems division has been together for nearly four months. And we've made significant progress capitalizing on the combination. We are working to streamline the sales and marketing organization, leverage operational synergies and coordinate R&D efforts. When we are done, we expect to have an even stronger position as a market leader in commercial infrared. Overall, commercial Systems division revenue in Q1 was $129 million, an increase of 17% compared to the combined first quarter results of Thermography and CVS a year ago. Operating income for Q1 was $34 million, up 25% from the prior year, while operating margin was a very strong 26%.
The promising signs of an economic recovery we saw in the fourth quarter were sustained throughout Q1 and led to healthy growth across most product lines.
Thermography revenue in Q1 was $75.6 million, an increase of 18% from the first quarter of 2009. Excluding the impact of currency, Thermography revenue grew 11%. Operating margins were 27%, up from 25% last year, due to better gross margins and operating leverage.
The U.S. improved substantially in the first quarter as growth in both the mid-range and the high-volume segments accelerated. Asia-Pacific continues its strong growth across most product lines, applications and countries. EMEA revenue was up only slightly. However, as the economic recovery in most European countries lagged the modest recovery in the United States.
We made some changes to our organization in Europe and expect better performance in the second half of 2010. Thermography unit volume increased over 40% compared to last year, a substantially better result than in 2009. Volumes were up across almost all product lines, indicating a return to the broad-based, multi-application demand drivers we experienced prior to the economic downturn.
Turning to Commercial Vision Systems, revenue was $53.4 million, an increase of 16% compared to the first quarter a year ago. Backlog remained very strong at $101 million, down just $2 million from year end. Operating income for Q1 was $13.8 million, up 22% from the prior year and the highest in CVS history. Operating margins were 26%, up 1% from the prior year, due to higher gross margins, which were partially offset by increased operating expenses.
Demand in the security and surveillance market was excellent as worldwide orders were up over 30% from the first quarter of the prior year, driven by outstanding growth in Europe. Unit growth was up nearly 60%, continuing the trend towards lower-priced short and mid-range uncooled cameras purchased with private industry funding. Our global distribution network now boasts 433 dealers worldwide, up nearly 100 from a year ago and reflecting our focus on expanding distribution for long-term growth.
In the maritime market, orders were up dramatically compared to the prior year and reached the highest quarterly level ever. Demand was strong across product lines from the top-of-the-line Voyager system to the new M-series multi-sensor system to the new First Mate handheld camera. The Maritime business has great promise for the future. 
Demand in Cores and Components, the largest CVS segment, was down slightly from the first quarter of 2009, due primarily to the timing of orders from some of our major military OEMs. The Auto segment, which has been slow for most of 2009, grew significantly during the first quarter, reflecting the addition of a second large OEM, as well as improved take rates.
Recently, we launched a new segments within CVS called Personal Vision Systems. This segment was created to drive growth of our commercial handheld system for law enforcement, security professionals and personnel use. The H-Series handheld camera has sold nearly 2,000 units since introduction nine months ago.
We continue to introduce new products at a rapid rate. In Q1, we launched three new models, including the world's first commercial high-definition IR camera, the Tau 640 uncooled camera core, which utilizes our first-ever 17-micron bolometer. And we leveraged the short-wave infrared expertise from the recently acquired Salvador Imaging team in Colorado Springs to develop and launch the Tau short-wave infrared camera core. Looking forward, we continue to see strong performance for the combined Commercial Systems business as the worldwide economy stabilizes and we effectively execute our high-volume, low-cost growth strategy.
Before I conclude my comments, I'd like to take the opportunity to thank my friend and former colleague, Arne Almerfors, for delivering to me a very well-run Thermography business. After getting more familiar with this business over the last four months, I'm even more confident that this business' prospects for the future are very bright. With that, let me now turn the call over to Bill Sundermeier to comment on the results of the Government Systems business.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andy. For the first quarter, Government Systems revenue was $158.3 million, a decrease of 2% from the prior year. Q1 operating income was $62.8 million, was down 14% primarily due to revenue mix and increased operating expenses. Operating margi
componenttext:
Thank you, Andy. For the first quarter, Government Systems revenue was $158.3 million, a decrease of 2% from the prior year. Q1 operating income was $62.8 million, was down 14% primarily due to revenue mix and increased operating expenses. Operating margins of 40% remained very strong in the quarter.
First quarter order activity was a bit better than expected, and our backlog of $418 million at March 31 was only $15 million lower than year end. We received over 80 orders during the quarter, the value of which was split nearly evenly between domestic and international. Airborne applications represented the majority of the orders with ground-based applications a strong second. In the U.S., delayed procurement decisions related to Afghan surge requirements are slowing order activity. We do not expect this situation to improve in the second quarter, but the pipeline remains healthy and we expect better orders in the second half.
In the force protection area, we received orders totaling $21.7 million from the U.S. Navy for our Star SAFIRE III stabilized multi-sensor systems and RECON III handheld binoculars to support the Marine Corps Ground-Based Operations Surveillance System, the G-BOSS program. This award supports near-term program requirements and is an interim award before the expected program of record process, which we believe will coincide with the fiscal year 2012 budget. 
In addition, the Army recently released a request for information related to the integrated tower needs of the BETTS-C program. This RFI may relate to interim requirements prior to the Army's planned program of record for BETTS-C. We are pleased with this recent activity from both the Marines and Army as it supports the premise that our force protection solutions are and will continue to be critically important.
Q1 was also a solid quarter in the airborne markets. We received a $12.4 million order from the Army for Star SAFIRE systems for Black Hawk MEDEVAC helicopters and a $13.5 million order from the Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane division for our BRITE Star II laser designation multi-sensor systems for Marine Corps and Navy applications. We received two other sizable orders for the BRITE Star II totaling $15 million. Further demonstrating the widespread adoption of our flagship designation platform.
A key area of growth for government system's is in the military vehicle applications for targeting IED detection, situational awareness and driver vision enhancement. We have leveraged our airborne multi-sensor system and uncooled low-cost system expertise to develop an extensive product portfolio for these emerging applications and see a strong pipeline of demand. In fact, early in Q2, we received a delivery order for $20.9 million under a $35.2 million IDIQ for the LRGM-VAS program, which will utilize our talent-stabilized multi-sensor system.
The Government Systems division has the broadest product portfolio in its history and is targeting more applications than ever before. To take advantage of the opportunity, we have increased our investment in sales and marketing. In particular, we are increasing our Washington, D.C. presence to better position us early in the procurement process.
Looking toward the remainder of 2010, we continue to believe Government Systems revenue will be flat to slightly up during the year based on the current level of backlog and the factor order forecast. Our objective as we progress through the year is to build a strong order book for 2011, as we work through planned mix changes. We also expect operating margins will hover around Q1 levels throughout the remainder of the year. That concludes my comments. Let me turn the call back over to Earl.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Bill. We are seeing a good recovery in our Commercial business and expect strong growth from it in the rest of the year. Our Government System business as Bill reported is on plan and its expanding sales footprint and marketing activities
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Bill. We are seeing a good recovery in our Commercial business and expect strong growth from it in the rest of the year. Our Government System business as Bill reported is on plan and its expanding sales footprint and marketing activities are positioning us for long-term growth.
In all our markets, we continue to focus on improving our operations, expanding our distribution, proving the quality of our products and in leading in promising gross growth markets. We have a significant cash position, no debt after we retire our convertible bonds in June, and a very strong cash flow. This will enable us to continue the strategy of using our financial strength to make value-creating acquisitions, invest in our existing business and when appropriate, repurchase our own common stock.
We did not acquire any of our own stock in Q1, and still have nearly 17 million shares authorized for repurchase. We will continue to seek opportunities to buy back our shares in the future. The M&A market, while difficult to predict, has some interesting opportunities for FLIR, and we continue to be very active in that market.
We've had some questions recently about whether FLIR intends to begin paying a dividend. This is a topic we regularly evaluate, and we will continue to do so. Our size and our cash flow can certainly support a meaningful dividend. But given the opportunities we see in front of us, and the likely significant increase in personal dividend tax rates next year, we do not intend to institute a pay out in the near future.
Before I turn the call over to Steve for his review of the finances in detail, I'd like to again thank our dedicated employees for their terrific focus, execution and their contribution to FLIR's continuing success. With that, Steve?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Earl. Revenue for the first quarter of 2010 totaled $287.3 million, an increase of 6% from the same quarter last year. Revenue from Government Systems was $158.3 million, 2% less from the first quarter of 2009, while Commercial Systems revenue
componenttext:
Thank you, Earl. Revenue for the first quarter of 2010 totaled $287.3 million, an increase of 6% from the same quarter last year. Revenue from Government Systems was $158.3 million, 2% less from the first quarter of 2009, while Commercial Systems revenue was $129 million, an increase of 17% over first quarter 2009.
Revenue from our Commercial division of $129 million is comprised of some Thermography revenue of $75.6 million, an increase of 18% over first quarter 2009, of which, approximately 7% of the increase was due to currency due to a weaker dollar as compared to the first quarter of 2009. Revenue from the Commercial Vision Systems of $53.4 million was an increase of 16% as compared to the first quarter of 2009. For the quarter, revenue was distributed 55% from Government Systems, 26% from Thermography and 19% from Commercial Vision Systems. Our international revenues for the quarter were 42% of total revenue, while revenues from the U.S. government sales accounted for 38% of consolidated revenue during the period, down from 45% of revenue for the first quarter of 2009.
We closed the quarter with a 12-month backlog of $543 million, a decrease of approximately 4% or $20 million less than our backlog in year-end 2009. By division, backlog amounted to Government Systems, $418 million; Thermography, $24 million; and Commercial Vision Systems, $101 million, representing declines from year-end 2009 by all divisions of $15 million, Government Systems were 3%, Thermography, $3 million or 11%; and Commercial Vision Systems of $2 million or 2%.
Gross margins for the current quarter was 57.6% as compared to 58% for the first quarter of last year and as compared to 56.5% from the fourth quarter of 2009. Research and development expenses of $24.8 million were 8.6% of revenue for the quarter, as compared to $22.4 million or 8.2% of revenue for the first quarter of 2009. Selling, general and administrative expenses first quarter of 2010 of $56.2 million were 19.6% of sales, as compared to $51.9 million or 19.1% from the same period in 2009. Earnings from operations for the quarter totaled $84.3 million or 29.4% of revenue, as compared to $83.4 million or 30.6% of revenue first quarter 2009.
Interest expense for the quarter totaled $1.2 million, as compared to $2.8 million for the same period last year. The quarterly expense relates to the remaining $58.5 million of convertible notes and the decrease from the year-over-year expenses due to the conversion of the Notes and common stock in 2009. During the quarter, the company earned $254,000 of interest income and $53,000 of other income per comprised of currency loss of shorter than $14,000, offset by $264,000 of other miscellaneous income. For the first quarter of 2009, the currency gain was $896,000. Based on the anticipated mix of foreign and domestic income for the full year, the effective tax rate for the quarter was 7.33%.
For the first quarter, net earnings are $55.9 million or $0.35 per diluted share. The 3% increase in net earnings compares to a net earnings of $54.3 million and an equivalent $0.35 per diluted share for the same quarter 2009. We finished the quarter with cash of approximately $462 million, as compared to year-end 2009 cash balance of $422 million. Our cash provided from operating activities during the quarter totaled $82.2 million. Cash used in investing activities of $37.9 million was primarily applied to capital expenditures in the amount of $36.9 million, of which included the acquisition of a facility in Santa Barbara of $29 million.
Depreciation during the quarter amounted to $7.1 million. Cash provided by financing activities during the quarter of $1.6 million is primarily due to the cash benefit from stock option exercises. Cash balances at March 31 were reduced by $6.2 million, due to the effective exchange rates during the quarter.
As mentioned earlier, the company expects to convert or redeem the remainder of its $58.5 million of convertible notes during the second quarter. Thus today, we will be providing notice to the trustee of the company's 3% convertible senior debentures of our intent to redeem the debentures on June 8 of 2010. As required by the indenture governing the debentures, we will also be notifying the holders of their rights to require the company to repurchase the debentures on June 1, 2010.
The specific terms and conditions of this redemption and this repurchase right will be contained in separate notices mailed on or about May 5, 2010 by the trustees to the holders of the debentures. The debentures are currently convertible into shares of our common stock. In the expected event that holders convert their debentures into common stock prior to redemption date, there will be no impact on earnings per share or cash flow. In the event some or all of the holders do not convert prior to redemption, such holders will receive the face value of their debentures in cash, which will reduce cash but also reduce FLIR's diluted fully diluted share count and may subsequently increase earnings per share. This concludes the summary, Earl. I'll turn the call back to you.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Steve. Maybe I'll go off script for a minute. As I think most of you know, this was Steve's last call as our CFO.And this presents me the opportunity to reminisce a little bit. Steve and I joined in 2000. The company had, I believe, $10
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Steve. Maybe I'll go off script for a minute. As I think most of you know, this was Steve's last call as our CFO.
And this presents me the opportunity to reminisce a little bit. Steve and I joined in 2000. The company had, I believe, $100 million in debt. We were doing about $160 million in revenue and about 11% of our revenue went to pay for the debt, I think, something on that order. By the end of next quarter, this quarter, Q2, we will probably have $500,000 in cash, no debt whatsoever, which is kind of interesting that we just got rid of the last bit of it.
A company that's gone during that roughly ten years from a market capital of $70 million to $4-something billion today. Much of that has been due to Steve's steady hand, calm approach to life, you can tell by how he presents our numbers each quarter, and his unswerving, if you will, dedication to doing things right. That was very much appreciated, Steve. We will miss you. Tony has big shoes to fill in many ways. We would like to come up and sit on your porch and looked out at your vineyards some day if you'll let us. We hope you come back and see us many times. We will indeed miss you. We look forward to see how Tony handles this next year, next quarter. And again, all of us at FLIR are sincerely in your debt for everything you've done for us.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess this question is more for Andy. We've seen really nice margin improvement in Commercial Vision. And could you maybe just give us a little color what's going on there? I know you've had a lot of success across the board with new product introductio
componenttext: I guess this question is more for Andy. We've seen really nice margin improvement in Commercial Vision. And could you maybe just give us a little color what's going on there? I know you've had a lot of success across the board with new product introductions, and Thermography and Commercial division. But we've seen some nice sequential gains here ,and is this kind of a sustainable level?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Peter, I think that the level is sustainable. It's a result of -- this quarter was particularly good because of the volume of shipments that we did. So we did get some nice operating leverage. In the Thermography business we had very high shipments i
componenttext: Yes, Peter, I think that the level is sustainable. It's a result of -- this quarter was particularly good because of the volume of shipments that we did. So we did get some nice operating leverage. In the Thermography business we had very high shipments in that business during the quarter. And we had favorable mix in the Commercial Vision Systems business. And that can vary a little bit quarter-to-quarter depending on the mix of product that we ship that is produced in the factory in Santa Barbara versus product that we shipped that is produced by Bill's division in Sweden. Of course, in those cases, the company still realizes all the margin. But in some cases, where I have a high shipment quarter where I'm shipping a lot of product out of Bill's factory from Sweden for border programs and it pulls the CVS margins down a little bit.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually Steve, they're more than sustainable.
componenttext: Actually Steve, they're more than sustainable.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Earl, I wanted talk about capital spending. And it looks like we're starting to witness some momentum in the both domestic and international capital spending market. Now I guess, what I wanted to talk to you about was how quarterly correlated is the comme
componenttext: Earl, I wanted talk about capital spending. And it looks like we're starting to witness some momentum in the both domestic and international capital spending market. Now I guess, what I wanted to talk to you about was how quarterly correlated is the commercial segment with the improvements in the spending environment? And where should we expect to note the greatest volume increases going forward?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: That's an interesting question. As we drive the price down of our products, which Commercial is doing, we should be less susceptible to the "capital cycles". And I don't know that we've really seen that yet. I think we still are at least now but when you
componenttext: That's an interesting question. As we drive the price down of our products, which Commercial is doing, we should be less susceptible to the "capital cycles". And I don't know that we've really seen that yet. I think we still are at least now but when you think about selling, for example, to the boating industry and some of those, those are commercial, those are people taking money out of their pockets. I think in terms of correlation, Mike, we'll probably see less of it over the future in the Commercial Systems business than we have in the past. Clearly, we are susceptible to it, though. I mean if you look at Q4 in Thermography it's almost always very strong. And that's people spending capital money at the end of the year. So while I think it'll decline, I think right now it's probably a pretty good correlation as capital spending goes up. Particularly in our high-end Thermography and Commercial, both, we should see increases in those in that revenue.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And that's exactly where I was going with regard to the higher dollar pieces in the petro-chem plants, the healthcare industry, areas like that, that's really where I was focusing the attention of that question. So my take away is that, yes, indeed, as ca
componenttext: And that's exactly where I was going with regard to the higher dollar pieces in the petro-chem plants, the healthcare industry, areas like that, that's really where I was focusing the attention of that question. So my take away is that, yes, indeed, as cap spending does continue to improve, there's higher dollar areas in the Commercial business could potentially benefit. Is that a correct way to say it?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we saw it in Q1.
componenttext: I think we saw it in Q1.

componenttext: Steve, the first question I have for you with regards to the, I guess, updated thinking in terms of rate and G-BOSS at this point. You guys gave a little bit of insight into what's happening there. But just wanted to get your thoughts on sort of additional opportunities and maybe if there's been some additional color coming out of the OCO in terms of the BETTS-C funding on RAID.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Of course, with the G-BOSS order, we know that they wanted some additional systems to go in Afghanistan. Presently, we don't anticipate many other larger orders for them on the horizon. This was kind of a filling-in for them. On the Army side, we have don
componenttext: Of course, with the G-BOSS order, we know that they wanted some additional systems to go in Afghanistan. Presently, we don't anticipate many other larger orders for them on the horizon. This was kind of a filling-in for them. On the Army side, we have done several different exercises and potential opportunities there. But nothing firm on the horizon as RFI is the best indicator that we've had so far that they want additional units. There was certainly some commentary that was presented in a few days ago about how they wanted an initial 72 sites in Afghanistan. But what we're hearing so far is they're trying to move -- still trying to move equipment from Iraq to Afghanistan and the difficulties of doing so because of the road infrastructure over there. Until that gets settled they don't know final requirements supplying -- We don't anticipate any orders certainly Q2, it might happen in the second half.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the synergies that you're seeing between Commercial and Thermography, can you maybe talk a little bit about some of the opportunities you see there to leverage the two units?
componenttext: In terms of the synergies that you're seeing between Commercial and Thermography, can you maybe talk a little bit about some of the opportunities you see there to leverage the two units?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jonathan. The first one has been on the front-end of the business. So we've consolidated sales and marketing efforts globally between Thermography and CVS. And that's has a pretty significant pop from that, and that's part of what drove our orders i
componenttext: Sure, Jonathan. The first one has been on the front-end of the business. So we've consolidated sales and marketing efforts globally between Thermography and CVS. And that's has a pretty significant pop from that, and that's part of what drove our orders in Q1 as well. So the Thermography organization had a more well-established international sales capability, particularly with all the international subsidiaries that we're beginning to operate in. So we've now injected the CVS product line into each of those organizations, and we're already seeing some payoffs from that. On the operations side, there are a couple of synergies there. Certainly in the product-development side, we're working much more closely together on future product developments to spread radiometry across all products, spread Nexus networking technology across all products, those kinds of things. The calibration methodology used in Thermography is one that will be propagated into CVS as well. And then the last thing that I'll mention is, is that the Thermography has a got a nice capability in terms of producing their own optics, for example. And that's something that we're going to spread across the CVS, have them producing optics and the [inaudible] for the CVS consumption, which we currently buy from external sources.

componenttext: Sure. Well, first, the sup doesn't look like it's going to get approved until closer to Memorial Day. So we'll start seeing money flow after that, start seeing some money flowing for servers, which is now handled by the RAID office, which is now called Integrated Tactical Systems. And I haven't quite nailed money down yet for the tower systems flowing. And of course, there's a [inaudible] that's coming in effective in October. And that's fairly lined out in the budget. So we know what's going on there. Hopefully, some of that will end up coming before if you will, sparing for additional units, and the best view I can give you now.

componenttext: We track it every quarter actually, Tim, with some degree of fidelity and I looked at that Q1 and it's still running right at that kind of 60/40 split. So we have seen it move a little bit more towards the commercial or industrial type funded. And when I say that, also that analysis is limited only to the CVS business at present, it's not including the Thermography revenue.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is something that we've watched for quite a long time. And we've been in the SWR business for some time. Indigo has had the capability of manufacturing SWR detectors for many years. But we really hadn't invested much in the back end of the cam
componenttext: Steve, this is something that we've watched for quite a long time. And we've been in the SWR business for some time. Indigo has had the capability of manufacturing SWR detectors for many years. But we really hadn't invested much in the back end of the camera. So we had a fairly large, not very feature-rich camera that really had grown non-competitive. Prior to our acquiring Indigo, they were using those detectors primarily in the telecom business for DWDM activity. Since then, there's been a growing level of interest from the Army on the use of SWR detectors for night vision and fused sensor activities to include the MANTIS program. And we've taken an interest in that. We think that we have the ability to offer the same kind of value-add in terms of innovation that we've done with our Tau camera core and the uncooled space in the SWR space. So what we've done is as it turns out there's quite a bit of expertise in this area and the acquisition that we made in Colorado Springs, the Salvador imaging company. When we initially acquired then we talked about EMCCD capabilities they have, but they also have very good capability and high-resolution visual and in SWR. The detector that we're using at present is the detector that is our readout. So it's an Indigo readout, which is I think a very competitive from a feature-standpoint readout in the market. And the current detectors we're using, we're actually have a third-party to do the in-gas piece of it, not because we're not capable of doing it, we are capable of doing it. But frankly, we're so busy with MC and titanium oxide that we don't have the capacity to sort of divert for a small volume of SWR. But our intention is that once the SWR business ramps up, we will bring the Indian piece back in-house and do it ourselves. What we've done that's unique here is that we're taking we basically made a Tau in-gas camera. So it's got the very attractive characteristics of small size, weight, low power consumption, ease of integration with the Tau family. And our goal there is to provide to our system OEMs and into our own internal capability the ability to choose various different Tau cameras.  A Tau camera for a long-wave and a Tau camera for SWR, a TAU camera for low-light color, those kind of capabilities.  And we think that will be very attractive to both our internal customers and our OEMs, UAV users and so forth.

componenttext: Well, they are certainly the leading edge of users of new technology in the U.S. military. But we've got lot of OEM-level interest in this technology. So gimbal manufacturers like ourselves in both internal and external, so you'll see those sensors going into multi-sensor suited gimbals that will go out to people well-beyond special operations forces.

componenttext: Yes, Jim, we are actually in an earlier question that was posed -- really called to this, the increase in capital spending. So, Arne had made comments in previous conference calls noting that the high-end of the business, the GasFindIR business, our P-Series, and to some extend our T-Series, which is a mid-range product that's slowed down pretty considerably with economic downturn. And as capital spending has responded, we've seen a pretty nice resurgence in all three of those areas. So that's been a positive thing for us. We also made some changes to the T-Series line to make it more competitive. And that's had a very favorable response during the year.

componenttextpreview: Sure. Just on the EMEA business, two things there. One is the economic recovery is happening slower than the rest of the world. I think it's kind of to be expected. They sort of got the flu after the rest of the world too. The second thing is, is we've ma
componenttext: Sure. Just on the EMEA business, two things there. One is the economic recovery is happening slower than the rest of the world. I think it's kind of to be expected. They sort of got the flu after the rest of the world too. The second thing is, is we've made some fairly significant organizational changes in the EMEA region. And that, I think, had a knock-on effect in terms that will take a few months to roll through the system. But then I think we'll be much better coming out of that. The Asia market continues to do very well and it's not just China. We've had very good response in Japan, in Korea. The only part of APAC that did not perform well in Q1, but we're starting to see it recover now, is Australia.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just as it relates to the long-range ground mobility loss. And I saw some comments a couple of weeks ago from Undersecretary Ash Carter. I don't know if his comments were more just rhetoric but he was talking about a potential to 20-fold in
componenttext: And then maybe just as it relates to the long-range ground mobility loss. And I saw some comments a couple of weeks ago from Undersecretary Ash Carter. I don't know if his comments were more just rhetoric but he was talking about a potential to 20-fold increase in camera sensors, both on an aerostat and mass-mounted level. Does this order stem from that needed demand in Afghanistan? And could there be truth to his statements, I mean are you guys just seeing more opportunities out there?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Mr. Carter has certainly generated a lot of excitement in that area with his statements there. I think it's he's very enamored with aerostat -- look at his testimony. And certainly, UAVs was also a large part of it. The 20-fold was definitely in ref
componenttext: Well, Mr. Carter has certainly generated a lot of excitement in that area with his statements there. I think it's he's very enamored with aerostat -- look at his testimony. And certainly, UAVs was also a large part of it. The 20-fold was definitely in reference to the aerostats. And I think that what we're going to see is more aerostats that was a Lockheed award in Q1 for, I think it was 17 for their PDDS program. Those do not have our sensors on it. They have a Canadian gimbal on there. We have through the JWins [ph] program which really started off the rate program my 35 sensors that are for over 20 aerostats that are in theater. And we see some other opportunities coming on to be on other aerostats. So I think that, that will increase but I think the aerostat portion isn't going to be as big, for example, as the towers. Just because the expense and they're putting them over major cities as compared to the forward-operating bases. And I mentioned earlier, we do still see that there are requirement numbers being generated for additional tower-based systems. I'm doubting this 20-fold more tower-based systems. I think it's more fill-in for their identified forward-operating basis, which they want to ramp up to in Afghanistan.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe for Andy, I know last quarter, you guys talked about on the nuclear side, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission providing kind of a tailwind way with their mandate. Is there any update on that market? Do you see what were the kind of units like to that
componenttext: Maybe for Andy, I know last quarter, you guys talked about on the nuclear side, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission providing kind of a tailwind way with their mandate. Is there any update on that market? Do you see what were the kind of units like to that segment this quarter? And what are your expectations going forward?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the requirement actually requires that the systems be up and running by April of this year. We did see order flow in Q1 coming from that. We're actually going to see some order flow in Q2 coming from it as well for two reasons. One is that the requi
componenttext: Well, the requirement actually requires that the systems be up and running by April of this year. We did see order flow in Q1 coming from that. We're actually going to see some order flow in Q2 coming from it as well for two reasons. One is that the requirement seems to getting pushed to the right a little bit. And the second is, there's a second area of this nuclear power plants called OCA, the owner-controlled area, that is emerging as a requirement for coverage as well. So I think that this is something that is going to be with us for most of the year.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the first is uses of cash. You have been generating cash at a pretty rapid rate clip right now. You talked about the fact that initiating a dividend doesn't make that much sense. Could you sort of prioritize both regarding some of these converts w
componenttext: I think the first is uses of cash. You have been generating cash at a pretty rapid rate clip right now. You talked about the fact that initiating a dividend doesn't make that much sense. Could you sort of prioritize both regarding some of these converts what the use of cash would be? Share buybacks to further acquisitions? And then on acquisitions itself, strategically, are you looking at further vertical integration, new markets, you've made some acquisitions, you look at distribution. Could you also discuss your distribution strategy for your non-government systems side?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Use of cash is very important to us. When you do our numbers over the long-run and you look at what the effects of how well we deploy our cash, it has a significant impact on the value of our stock over the next ten years. We know that, we've put those nu
componenttext: Use of cash is very important to us. When you do our numbers over the long-run and you look at what the effects of how well we deploy our cash, it has a significant impact on the value of our stock over the next ten years. We know that, we've put those numbers in and we realize we've got to deploy this cash in a way that's better for shareholders than just sitting on it. So we will deploy it. The question is, what's the next -- historically, our mix has been roughly been half and half. It's been half share buyback and half acquisitions. Right now, we've built up a pretty good pool of, and it looks like we'll continue to do that. We've also done most of our backward integration already. In other words, both businesses, Commercial and Government, are pretty well backward integrated. So the vast majority of the things that we need from backwards integration, we already control. Going forward, we made one acquisition that was more in the distribution channel, and that was Extech and that's worked out fairly well for us. So I think clearly one of our strategies particularly on the Commercial side, is to look at where we could expand into the distribution part of our business and where we think that will give us more  entry into the market. And there are some opportunities in there we're exploring today. In those areas, I think there's some technology opportunities we may be able to have. There's multiple sensors that can be used in multiple applications and we're looking at some different businesses there. And I think there's some public knowledge as to what's for sale. So we'll look at some of those opportunities and there are two or three now that are actively being shopped, if you will. We need to deploy our cash. We need to do it in a good way and hopefully by the end of this year, we will have had an acquisition at least maybe two that are significant for the long-range future of our company.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just looking at the distribution strategy you've had recently and more the pricing strategy on the Commercial Vision System side. I mean, in Thermography you've talked about price elasticity and creating new market bring down prices all the time.
componenttext: And then just looking at the distribution strategy you've had recently and more the pricing strategy on the Commercial Vision System side. I mean, in Thermography you've talked about price elasticity and creating new market bring down prices all the time. On the Commercial Vision Systems side, could you give us some color as to how you're looking at sort of penetrating some new markets and the pricing in the market. You've demonstrated some very good operating margins over there this quarter. Whether -- you also mentioned that you think those margins are sustainable. Does that mean that pricing over there is right and all you've got to do is get distribution? Or do you think it is more of a penetration gain through distribution or still some price elasticity that can be gotten there?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll just overview and then let Andy give the details. The price elasticity argument in the Commercial Vision's business is just as strong as it is in Thermography. Somebody asked earlier on what are we learning by merging these businesses. It's pre
componenttext: Well, I'll just overview and then let Andy give the details. The price elasticity argument in the Commercial Vision's business is just as strong as it is in Thermography. Somebody asked earlier on what are we learning by merging these businesses. It's pretty clear they have the exact same ideas in mind in terms of just driving the price down. One of the best examples is the new First Mate we've sold into the boating industry where we've brought the price down significantly from any product that was available in the past. And it's had a remarkable number of unit sales as a result. Andy, you can surely elaborate more on this.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, just two things, Ajit. First, you asked about the distribution strategy and it really comes down to four things for us. One, more is better. We want a lot of distribution. Two, we want them well-trained and well-equipped in terms of understanding th
componenttext: Well, just two things, Ajit. First, you asked about the distribution strategy and it really comes down to four things for us. One, more is better. We want a lot of distribution. Two, we want them well-trained and well-equipped in terms of understanding the technology and the tools to sell it. We tend to have non-exclusive distributors. And we want global coverage and those are the four main points we're working on the distribution side. On the price elasticity side, we believe these are very elastic markets and continue to bring prices down. Earl mentioned the First Mate. That's been a very successful product for us. We've sold 2,000 units in the first nine months of its introduction., which we're pretty pleased with. And to support that, though, on your point, we don't see the gross margins declining and so to support that we've got to lower our costs, and we're spending aggressively in the R&D side to do that, to develop a technology that will continue to lower cost at the core sensor technology level.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Just one last comment. In some ways, the Commercial Vision business, Andy's older business, is even more price elastic than the Thermography business because the potential buying universe is so much bigger. And typically, do not have the industrial backgr
componenttext: Just one last comment. In some ways, the Commercial Vision business, Andy's older business, is even more price elastic than the Thermography business because the potential buying universe is so much bigger. And typically, do not have the industrial background, for example. So selling to a police force, you're going to have to have significantly lower prices to really penetrate that market.

componenttext: The question is for Andy. On the changes in Europe that are likely -- that are expected to lead to better results in the second half. If you could provide a little color on what it is you're doing and what the magnitude financially would be of these changes?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of things. At the leadership level, the individual at the top of the organization in the EMEA group, the fellow that was running the organization for CVS has now taken over for both CVS and Thermography. And he's a quite an experienced guy
componenttext: Well, a couple of things. At the leadership level, the individual at the top of the organization in the EMEA group, the fellow that was running the organization for CVS has now taken over for both CVS and Thermography. And he's a quite an experienced guy who's been with the company for more than ten years and has worked both in Thermography and CVS in the past. So he knows both markets quite well. In terms of the specific changes that we're making there, we actually reduced headcount there. We have some redundancy issues that we've dealt with. So it actually, in terms of Q1, had a negative impact and our expenses were up because there were some redundancy cost. Those will come out in subsequent quarters. But he has streamlined the organization. I think he's clarified some lines of distribution between the way we handle direct sales and distribution sales, specifically in the Thermography business. And we're leveraging up a combined sales force for Thermography and CVS there. In terms of the measure of that effect financially, like I say, it had a negative effect on expenses in Q1. which we'll roll through, and I think it also had a negative effect on orders because it was kind of surgery there that we'll have to recover from. But moving forward, based on the results that I've seen from this individual in the past ten years, I expect good things. And I don't know how good that will be. But I would hope that we would be able to see the same kind of growth rates that we've excuse in the U.S. market as the economy recovers there.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill or Earl, just a clarification. We were talking about short-wave infrared. Now, the Army wants to move away from the green-screen night vision. They want to move to more color and short-wave IR capabilities. And something that's not really in your swe
componenttext: Bill or Earl, just a clarification. We were talking about short-wave infrared. Now, the Army wants to move away from the green-screen night vision. They want to move to more color and short-wave IR capabilities. And something that's not really in your sweet spot and not really a core business is the helmet-mounted IR market. And with the Army and SOCOM trying to  go after these technologies embedded, the short-wave infrared embedded into the goggles. Do you think that this is an opportunity that we could expect to see FLIR move into over the next, say, two to three years?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill is best to answer that.
componenttext: Bill is best to answer that.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, I think that's definitely an area that we could move into. I know that the Army -- all the forces are exploring other options to IR 2 devices. I don't think that they're going to go away completely. They're certainly moving into a lot of fused conce
componenttext: Sure, I think that's definitely an area that we could move into. I know that the Army -- all the forces are exploring other options to IR 2 devices. I don't think that they're going to go away completely. They're certainly moving into a lot of fused concepts moving forward. And IR 2, when you get the opportunity to see this Tau-version of the short-wave, it is the closest thing to making something very small and lower power for that kind of application. And that's really what's driving these head-mounted and soldier devices, is we need to get them small, lightweight and low power. And we're the kind of company I think could figure that out in a few years.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Kila, and Ill be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the FLIR Systems second quarter 2010 financial results conference call.I will now turn the call over to Mr. Whit Davis, Senior
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Kila, and Ill be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the FLIR Systems second quarter 2010 financial results conference call.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Whit Davis, Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of FLIR Systems. Sir you may begin.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning or good afternoon, everyone. Before we begin this conference call I need to remind you that other than statements as to historical facts, the statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Pri
componenttext:
Good morning or good afternoon, everyone. Before we begin this conference call I need to remind you that other than statements as to historical facts, the statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform of 1995 and are based on our current expectations. Word such as expect, anticipate, intend, believe, estimates and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify such forward-looking statements. All of these statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to the press release we issued earlier today for a description of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those forecasted. The forward-looking statements we make today speak as of today and we do not undertake any obligation to update any such statements to reflect events or circumstances occurring after today.
Let me now turn call over to Earl Lewis, Chairman and CEO of FLIR Systems.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah. Well, thank you Whit. And thank you all for joining us this morning. We are very pleased with our performance in the second quarter. We earned $0.37 per share on a 19% increase in revenue or 9% if you exclude Raymarine. Our Commercial Vision Systems
componenttext:
Yeah. Well, thank you Whit. And thank you all for joining us this morning. We are very pleased with our performance in the second quarter. We earned $0.37 per share on a 19% increase in revenue or 9% if you exclude Raymarine. Our Commercial Vision Systems Business grew 27% in the quarter and our thermography grew through 7% in a very uneven economy.
Government systems performed very well, even as the U.S. funding delays continued. Gross margins and operating margins remained very strong and in line with our expectation. We exited the quarter with cash of 285 million no debt. On May 14th, we completed the acquisition of Raymarine the number one brand in the marine electronics industry for approximately $175 million net of cash.
The acquisition was attractive for several reasons; first Raymarine dramatically expanded our maritime distribution network which will enable us to sell more of our thermal images to this large unpenetrated market. Second, our distribution in the higher end commercial marine market will enable us to expand the breath of Raymarine's products. And third we believe the timing though this transaction is very good. We may be in the early stages of a recovery in the market.
And finally we see substantial opportunities to improve Raymarine's operating performance and to bring it more in line with that with the rest of FLIR. When we fully integrated we expect to have a large growing maritime business with margins similar to those that we currently enjoy.
With that, well let Andy to discuss the Commercial Systems Business. Go ahead, Andy.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank, Earl. Overall Commercial Systems division revenue in Q2 excluding Raymarine was 136 million, an increase of 16% compared to the second quarter results of Thermography in CVS a year ago.Operating income for Q2 excluding Raymarine was 36 million up
componenttext:
Thank, Earl. Overall Commercial Systems division revenue in Q2 excluding Raymarine was 136 million, an increase of 16% compared to the second quarter results of Thermography in CVS a year ago.
Operating income for Q2 excluding Raymarine was 36 million up 25% from the prior year. We experienced generally stable economic conditions in our markets around the world during the quarter with a notable exception of the thermography market in Germany. The thermography revenue in Q2 was 71.4 million an increase of 7% from the second quarter of 2009.
Operating margins were 23%. U.S. thermography revenue grew slightly in the quarter, while Asia Pacific continued its strong growth across most product lines applications, and countries. EMEA was down however, as economic conditions impacted our customer activity. We made some changes to our organization in Europe and expect to return to solid growth once these changes take effect in the economic conditions stabilize.
From an application perspective, electrical, building and gas imagining were all up nicely in the quarter. Test and measurement was flat and automation and R&D applications were down. Overall, thermography unit volumes increased 40% compared to last year, again illustrating the significant opportunities to penetrate price that last in low and mid range segments such as those addressed by our I 5, I 7 and T series products.
The invasion engine and thermography remain strong. In Q2 we launched the A-640 a new product platform for the factory automation market featuring a 17-micron 640 by 480 high resolutions, high speed camera for demanding process and production monitoring application. CVS had a very good second quarter, revenue was 64.7 million an increase of 27% compared to the second quarter a year ago.
Backlog remained very strong at 104 million up 3 million from Q1. CVS operating income for Q2 was 19.2 million up 45% from the prior year and the highest in CVS history by far. Operating margins were also a record at 30%, up 4 percentage points from the prior year due to favorable product mix, higher volumes and lower material costs.
Demand for CVS products was very strong around the world; growth in Asia was particularly robust as the front end integration of the CVS team with the larger more established thermography team in Asia helped generate demand.
Demand in the security and surveillance market was very strong and unit growth was up over 70% compared to last Q2. Of course in components, the largest CVS segment was up significantly from the second quarter of 2009 due to increased orders from several OEM customers for both cool and uncooled cores. The new Tau 17-micron uncooled core which we launched back in April at the SPIE conference is performing extremely well in the marketplace. We believe this camera is the most sensitive, most uniformed and most stable uncooled 17-micro camera available and based on customer interest we expect it to do very well in the marketplace.
Growth in auto segment is exceeding our expectations. In the first half of 2010, we shipped the same number of units as in all of 2009 and we expect 2010 volume to approximate the total that we shipped in 2008 and 2009 combined. In addition to our success with the Audi A8, Audi has added our camera to the A6 model which we believe could significantly add to our unit volumes overtime.
The recently launched personal vision system segment was created to drive growth of the commercial handheld systems for law enforcement, security professional and personal use. The initial product line with the segment the H series handheld camera has grown rapidly, since its launch and has sold over 1600 units in the first year. Were very pleased to welcome the Raymarine team to FLIR and are excited about the opportunities to grow their businesses while leveraging their brand and distribution for our core thermal business.
Since the acquisition in May, weve added thermal cameras to Raymarine's global marketing activity, reduced component supply constraints that were limiting growth and reorganized the management structure. We are also aligning the expense structure to be more in line with the FLIR model and working toward launch of Raymarine branded thermal cameras in time for the Fall Trade Show Season.
That concludes my comments. Let me now turn the call over to Bill Sundermeier to comment on the results in the Government System Business.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andy. In the second quarter, the Government Systems revenue was 167.9 million, an increase of 5% from the prior year. Q2 operating income of 65.8 million was down 9% primarily due to revenue mix and planned increases in operating expenses.Ope
componenttext:
Thank you, Andy. In the second quarter, the Government Systems revenue was 167.9 million, an increase of 5% from the prior year. Q2 operating income of 65.8 million was down 9% primarily due to revenue mix and planned increases in operating expenses.
Operating margins of 39% remained very strong in the quarter. Second quarter order activity was consistent with our expectations and continued to be impacted by slow U.S. procurement activity. Backlog was 375 million at June 30th, a decrease of 43 million from the prior quarter.
Order activity was once again split nearly, evenly between domestic and international. Ground based applications represented the majority of orders with airborne a strong second. Our leadership position and force protection applications is paying dividend beyond the rate platform. In Q2 we received a $14.1 million award from star technologies for Star SAFIRE 3 and Star SAFIRE HD multi-sensor systems to support the rapid fielding of the persistent and ground surveillance system which provides force protection to U.S. nationals in Afghanistan.
We are pleased to see the success we have enjoyed with the ray platform carry over to new force protection applications, utilizing advanced sensors such as the Star HD. There was no order activity in the quarter for either the G-Boss or BETSS-C programs and we do not expect any large orders for the remainder of the year. However, we may receive small orders for maintenance, sparing or service related demand.
While U.S. order activity remains slow, strong international activity continued unabated with both order size and breadth increasing during the quarter. Our established sales and customer support presence in numerous locations across the Middle East are key to our strong position in this marketplace.
During Q2 we received two contracts in excess of 11 million to supply a Middle East allies ground forces with recon 3 thermal binoculars. These ground systems will compliment the nearly 60 FLIR airborne sensors this ally is already operating. Also in the Middle East we received a $5 million order from the navy of Kuwait for C-FLIR 3 systems, we look forward to continue growth in other Middle Eastern countries that are working to improve their security.
In Europe, we received a multimillion dollars order from finish Defense Company, Patria Oy for the direct fire sight system. These units will be deployed on Patrias 120-millimeter unmanned mortar turret which can be mounted on to various track in a wheel chassis. The remote weapon stations site market is emerging and we are well positioned to participate in its growth.
In South America, we received an $8 million order to supply Star SAFIRE III to support Brazil's army, navy and air force. We enjoy a long-term relationship with the Brazilian military and look forward to additional potential orders for this program. The interest in attendance to this year's Farnborough air show which is happening this week has been very good. We have been show casing our new Star SAFIRE HD Gen II with full HD imagers for IR, visible and low-light operation.
We are also showing our new HD common architecture solutions which are being well received by aircraft integrators. Our outlook for all of 2010 hasn't changed. We see Government Systems revenue as flat to slightly up for the year, based on the current level of backlog and the order forecast. Our current outlook for the U.S. is a bit uncertain, but we do expect third quarter orders to be better than what we have experienced in Q1 and Q2.
That concludes my comments. Let me turn it back to Earl.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. FLIR continues to perform well across all its markets and geographies. We are especially pleased with the recent growth and profitability trends in our Commercial Vision Systems business and with the continued strong operating margins gen
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. FLIR continues to perform well across all its markets and geographies. We are especially pleased with the recent growth and profitability trends in our Commercial Vision Systems business and with the continued strong operating margins generated by our Government business.
Our strategy to expand the market for infrared technology by driving down costs continues as our outstanding operating model. It does however appear to us that economic conditions remain hard to predict and that was actually written before Ben Bernanke said he couldn't do it.
This environment is problematic so we have decided that in this call we will leave our earnings per share outlook as we had at the end of the year. Our revenue outlook however will increase by approximately $100 million to reflect the impact of the Raymarine acquisition.
With this, now its my pleasure to turn this over to our new CFO to discuss the financials in detail. Tony.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Earl. Second quarter revenue increased 19% overall and 9% excluding Raymarine. Commercial vision systems increased 27% as a result of very good growth in virtually all geographies and market. Thermography sales increased 7% for the quarter and Asi
componenttext:
Thanks, Earl. Second quarter revenue increased 19% overall and 9% excluding Raymarine. Commercial vision systems increased 27% as a result of very good growth in virtually all geographies and market. Thermography sales increased 7% for the quarter and Asia was again very strong while Europe was impacted by uncertain economic environment.
Government systems revenue increased by 5%, entirely due to growth internationally. International revenue was 37% of the total NGS the highest in at least ten years. For the entire company, international revenue was 49% of the total compared with 41% in the second quarter of 2009. Sales to the U.S. Government represented 32% of total sales and 34% of sales excluding Raymarine compared with 41% in the second quarter of last year.
International sales as a percentage of our total was the highest in four years and our U.S. Government sales as a percentage of the total was the lowest in four years. Consolidated gross margin was 55.4% compared with 58.3% last year. Excluding Raymarine, order 2 2010 gross margin was 57.6%. The remaining difference compared to Q2 of last year was due to lower gross margin in Government systems resulting from an expected shift in mix.
Consolidated operating margin in the second quarter was 27.1% and 28.4% excluding Raymarine. This compares with an operating margin of 30.5% last Q2. Government systems operating income for the quarter was 65.8 million compared with 72.4 million in the second quarter of last year. GS operating margins remained very strong at 39.2% versus the record level of 45.2% reached in the second quarter of 2009.
Thermography reported operating income of 16.7 million for an operating margin of 23.4% up about 35 basis points from last year. CVSs operating income for the quarter of 19.2 million yielded a record operating margin of 29.7% up 3.6 percentage points from last year.
Corporate expenses for the quarter were 15.4 million including 3.2 million of expenses related to the Raymarine acquisition. This compares with 16.4 million in corporate expenses in quarter two of 2009. Raymarine performed very well, since the acquisition of May 14th, revenue was 27.2 million and operating income was 3.4 million from an operating margin of 12.6%.
Excluding reserves free structuring of approximately 1.4 million is contained in the Raymarine results, the Raymarine operating margin was 17.8%. The second quarter is a seasonally strong quarter for the marine electronics business, so we don't expect margins at this level for the second half of 2010, but we're very pleased with the progress being made to improve profitability at Raymarine.
We did not report any amortization of intangibles arising from the Raymarine transaction during Q2 as we have not yet completed the final purchase price allocation. Based on the current analysis we expect to record between 1.6 and $1.8 million per quarter of amortization relating to - amortization of intangibles related to Raymarine beginning in the third quarter of this year.
As a result, we expect Raymarine to be slightly dilutive to GAAP earnings per share in the second half. Changes in currency rates had a minor impact on our second quarter results. Excluding Raymarine, revenue growth in constant currency terms was 8% with the largest impact driven by the change in the Euro relative to the dollar.
Excluding Raymarine, approximately three quarters of consolidated second quarter revenue was reported in U.S. dollars, with the next largest currency, the Euro representing approximately 1/6 of the total and the remainder in the range of currency. Other income for the quarter totaled 1.9 million a swing of 3 million from last Q2. Included in this quarters other income was a currency gain of 576,000 and a gain on investments of 775,000.
Our tax rate for the quarter was 34.6% compared with 32% last Q2. The tax rate was unusually high in Q2 due to the continued delay in approving R&D tax credits in U.S. as well as the non-deductibility of the expenses associated with the Raymarine acquisition. We expect our rate for the full year to be in the range of 32 to 34%.
Cash flow from operations for the quarter totaled 42.7 million compared with 57.7 million in the second quarter of last year, due largely to a $20 million increase in net current assets excluding the impact of Raymarine. This increase was related to the timing of orders within the quarter.
Significant cash outlays in the quarter included 175 million net for the acquisition of Raymarine, 7 million for capital expenditures and 33 million for the repurchase of 1.2 million shares of common stock at an average price of $27.59 per share.
Major balance sheet changes for the quarter reflect the acquisition of Raymarine. Cash balances declined by 177 million, while other long term assets increased by 125 million reflects the access purchase price over the net asset value of Raymarine of 123 million. This balance will be re-categorized into goodwill and intangibles upon completion of the Raymarine purchase price allocation in Q3.
This concludes the summary of our second quarter financial results. Ill now turn it back to Earl.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010

So with that operator, can you open the lines for questions.

componenttext: Good morning, guys. Great quarter and congratulations Tony on your first opportunity. Just wanted to talk broadly first about the government business and particularly what your expectations are as we look at sort of backlog in 2011, given everything that's happening around defense budgets worldwide and sort of the delay that we are seeing in the supplemental at this point?

componenttext: Well, Bill is going to talk in detail on that, I am not. But I did have a chance to attend Farnborough with Bill in this week. And weve had a tremendous amount of interest in our products at Farnborough and this is a pretty good news particularly since that is international. And I do think the international side of our business is going to grow fairly well over the next year. As you know, this is a very difficult thing for us to forecast. It really is but our base business has been growing well and with the numbers we looked at recently.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Exact. We have a pretty good look into Q3 and of course, it is hard to predict what the Government is going to spend at the end of the fiscal year which is at the end of this quarter, although in the current climate we will see what that does bring and th
componenttext:
Exact. We have a pretty good look into Q3 and of course, it is hard to predict what the Government is going to spend at the end of the fiscal year which is at the end of this quarter, although in the current climate we will see what that does bring and that certainly will delay the supplemental, it is really hard to forecast how that money will flow. Typically, well get to see a flow a quarter or two afterwards. So maybe that will start flowing in Q4.
That makes it very difficult for us to predict the remainder of this year. But certainly, I mentioned in the script, Q3 looks much stronger than Q1 and Q2 from where we sit and Q4 is a little harder to predict but it looks like its going to be at least at the current run rate. And we certainly hoping to perhaps win some other programs and move that on up.

componenttext: We are certainly engaged in enough activity there. I mean, thats - we are not short of that as we have been adding staff in order to cover that in our business development model. Weve added quite a few people this year already. So we will see.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. And just as a follow up, now that you guys have had a little bit of time to digest the Raymarine acquisition, what is your, I guess full-year revenue target, I guess, operating margin targets and what are some of the low hanging fruit that are stil
componenttext: Great. And just as a follow up, now that you guys have had a little bit of time to digest the Raymarine acquisition, what is your, I guess full-year revenue target, I guess, operating margin targets and what are some of the low hanging fruit that are still left there in term of operating improvements?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: 100 million is the revenue number for the year for us for this stub year. That's what we added to guidance a minute ago. I have never liked the term low-hanging fruit. Everything you do in business is work and requires thought and has consequences.With
componenttext:
100 million is the revenue number for the year for us for this stub year. That's what we added to guidance a minute ago. I have never liked the term low-hanging fruit. Everything you do in business is work and requires thought and has consequences.
With that said, we think the business can be improved significantly. We have a new CEO if you will or President of Raymarine, a man we have known for a long time, Tom Saram [ph]. He is tackling every part of the business in terms of cost reductions, in order to improve gross margins, in terms of distribution channel, in terms of development of new products that are exciting. We just had to review with Tom a minute ago. I would say he's on track to improve every area of the business. That will take a while and I think it is safe to say that probably if you include the acquisition costs and everything, this year will not be accretive to our earnings. But absolutely it will be accretive next year.
