componenttext: Andy, just following on, on that question on Thermography. How much of the weakness, if we call it that, in Thermography is attributable to internal issues in your mind versus external forces?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it depends on who you ask. If you ask me, internal people will probably say, it's all management's fault. And if you ask the manager will tell you, it's all the economy. So it's hard to say, Tim. I think it's a mix of both things. I mean, given th
componenttext: I guess it depends on who you ask. If you ask me, internal people will probably say, it's all management's fault. And if you ask the manager will tell you, it's all the economy. So it's hard to say, Tim. I think it's a mix of both things. I mean, given the fact that we see such a high concentration in Germany, and there, we've had a fair amount of organizational tumult, I think that's certainly points to that being a problem. But you can't help but look at the news everyday and look at economic problems in Europe. So I think we got a little bit of both going on.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the rest of the world, if you will, was in pretty good shape. Given the world malaise that we seem to have, I didn't do the numbers. If you exclude the delta in Germany, what was our growth? But I think it would have been double-digit, I'm p
componenttext: Well, I think the rest of the world, if you will, was in pretty good shape. Given the world malaise that we seem to have, I didn't do the numbers. If you exclude the delta in Germany, what was our growth? But I think it would have been double-digit, I'm pretty sure of that. I didn't check it, but I'm pretty sure. They had a very good profit. We know we have a management issue with Germany, we'll fix that. I view this as pretty good quarter with that one exception. And then just the balance [ph] of the world.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick question for Bill as well, you mentioned potential of your spares and maintenance and some server's activity in the back half of the year. I was wondering if you can also comment on what might be behind or in addition to the PGSS order th
componenttext: And just a quick question for Bill as well, you mentioned potential of your spares and maintenance and some server's activity in the back half of the year. I was wondering if you can also comment on what might be behind or in addition to the PGSS order that you've already received, in other words, what kind of follow-on orders might you see in that program? And then what do you expect on G-BOSS and BETTS-C next year if you don't expect orders this year?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We did that with the PMS [ph] group, which is the group that's -- when the Ranger group became MS. If real focus was on Cerberus, and that's why I foreshadowed that, not expecting large system orders other than for the remainder of the year, we might get
componenttext: We did that with the PMS [ph] group, which is the group that's -- when the Ranger group became MS. If real focus was on Cerberus, and that's why I foreshadowed that, not expecting large system orders other than for the remainder of the year, we might get spare in there. And I think that might continue into the first half of next year. Certainly, we're going to be heading for the programming record for 2012, and that we might see orders for that second half of next year. But right now, they're in a process of still moving towers from Afghanistan and the other way around, Iraq to Afghanistan. And the Marine Corps seems to be somewhat satisfied with what they have. We're going to see just small orders, I think, for this second half of this year and the first half of next year until we have better definition of what the program of record could bring. The PGSS program is a nice program, and we may see more orders for that in the second half and see some requirements forming there but can't promise anything quite yet.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Brian Ruttenbur of Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Brian Ruttenbur of Morgan Keegan.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And you may have already mentioned this, but I missed it, how much of your backlog drop and the government area is directly related to G-BOSS and BETTS-C? And can you address that?
componenttext: And you may have already mentioned this, but I missed it, how much of your backlog drop and the government area is directly related to G-BOSS and BETTS-C? And can you address that?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we didn't actually give that number. We really haven't, but I think what we can tell you is that we come into Q3 with a de minimis amount of backlog in G-BOSS and BETTS-C deliveries. There's always going to be some service and that sort
componenttext: Well, I think that we didn't actually give that number. We really haven't, but I think what we can tell you is that we come into Q3 with a de minimis amount of backlog in G-BOSS and BETTS-C deliveries. There's always going to be some service and that sort of thing. But in terms of unit deliveries, we've got a very small backlog remaining of G-BOSS and BETTS-C.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So then the third quarter build in government has nothing to do with G-BOSS and BETTS-C? Is that correct?
componenttext: So then the third quarter build in government has nothing to do with G-BOSS and BETTS-C? Is that correct?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Do not anticipate any orders in Q3 for G-BOSS and BETTS-C.
componenttext: Do not anticipate any orders in Q3 for G-BOSS and BETTS-C.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct.
componenttext: Yes, correct.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so what are the main programs that are building back?
componenttext: Okay, so what are the main programs that are building back?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, we had ...
componenttext: Brian, we had ...

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We should get out their shipment schedule for the quarter.
componenttext: We should get out their shipment schedule for the quarter.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We had over 90 individual orders in Government Systems in Q2. As we've talked about before, our business isn't comprised particularly in a given quarter of deliveries, with the exception of what we've seen with RAID, G-BOSS, BETTS-C for the last several y
componenttext: We had over 90 individual orders in Government Systems in Q2. As we've talked about before, our business isn't comprised particularly in a given quarter of deliveries, with the exception of what we've seen with RAID, G-BOSS, BETTS-C for the last several years. Our order book and our delivery book is rarely comprised of four or five things that make up a significant percentage of it. And that's certainly true in Q3.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Peter Arment of Gleacher & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Peter Arment of Gleacher & Company.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, discussions with some of your people at the Farnborough Air Show alluded to a lot of the opportunities to display some of your competition on the international militaries, and you've given us some color there. But can you talk a little about what yo
componenttext: Bill, discussions with some of your people at the Farnborough Air Show alluded to a lot of the opportunities to display some of your competition on the international militaries, and you've given us some color there. But can you talk a little about what you're seeing in just border opportunities in general?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think worldwide, we see the importance of order applications and both Andy and I share that through OEMs and dealers, which has been very good. And as directly, we definitely see more U.S. opportunity, money shifting to DHS there for that as there
componenttext: Sure. I think worldwide, we see the importance of order applications and both Andy and I share that through OEMs and dealers, which has been very good. And as directly, we definitely see more U.S. opportunity, money shifting to DHS there for that as there was money there for SBI net, and it's in the funds, and they're starting to spend some of that. And certainly, internationally, all the Middle Eastern countries are very focused on border protection and security. And General Atomics just announced that they have a license to be able to show their Predator XP, their export version in the Middle East now. And that's primarily for monitoring borders and doing surveillance. So I still think that there's a very growing interests, both in the U.S. and abroad for border potential. I think we're going to see that in the second half of this year and next year as a growing part of our business.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's important to remember, there's been a couple of questions about others talking about getting into the International business as they see the U.S. Well, we've started to see -- well, we've seen good growth in our International Government
componenttext: Yes, I think it's important to remember, there's been a couple of questions about others talking about getting into the International business as they see the U.S. Well, we've started to see -- well, we've seen good growth in our International Government business for a long time, and we've really gotten traction in the last couple of years in those markets. So this isn't something that we're just starting. And a lot of the groundwork has been laid in a lot of the critical markets based on the activity that we've been doing for the last couple of years really in particular. So we're reminding you that the numbers that we just gave, 35%, 40% of our Government Systems business is currently coming from outside the U.S. That's a percentage that we see an opportunity to continue to grow. And I think it's a percentage that it's dramatically higher than most of the company that you guys are asking about.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And it has been growing. We have a track record of growing the international now for two years. It's been pretty outstanding.
componenttext: And it has been growing. We have a track record of growing the international now for two years. It's been pretty outstanding.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Paul Coster of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question comes from Paul Coster of JPMorgan.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So questions for Bill and Andy regarding margins. First of all, Andy, on the CVS side, it sounds like you're approaching record levels there. Is it sustainable? Is it going to change moving forward? And if so, why? And Bill, sounds like you're making some
componenttext: So questions for Bill and Andy regarding margins. First of all, Andy, on the CVS side, it sounds like you're approaching record levels there. Is it sustainable? Is it going to change moving forward? And if so, why? And Bill, sounds like you're making some investments below in operating expenses. And so can you elaborate as to what they are and what your outlook for your margins are? And that you mentioned, I think, a mix shift. Is that going to continue? Or is it a one-time thing?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll go ahead, Paul, this is Andy. CVS margins are going to move around a little bit as they have in the past. And that's driven by our mix. So to the extent that, for example, on delivering on border programs, we're selling through integrators and in buy
componenttext: I'll go ahead, Paul, this is Andy. CVS margins are going to move around a little bit as they have in the past. And that's driven by our mix. So to the extent that, for example, on delivering on border programs, we're selling through integrators and in buying product through GS, where they're produced by Bill Zachary. Those show up as CS [Commercial Systems] margins that are a little bit lower and pulled down by overall gross margin. And we've had very, very good success in the Middle East, in particular, border-programmed. So I've got a bunch of that revenue that will be going through the income statement in Q3 and Q4. So those may pull the CS margins down slightly, but it also adds internal margin to the GS division. So it's good for the company overall. The other thing that we're doing though is as we design new product, we strive to design products that have better gross margins. And we've been doing that since the formation of CVS back in Q2 of 2006, and I think you've seen that in the model that the margins have improved.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And on the Government Systems side, operating expenses have been planned to increase, primarily to expand our sales and marketing footprint. And we've pretty much done that the first half of this year with a little bit more expansion perhaps in the second
componenttext: And on the Government Systems side, operating expenses have been planned to increase, primarily to expand our sales and marketing footprint. And we've pretty much done that the first half of this year with a little bit more expansion perhaps in the second half, although we're going to try and hold our operating expenses relatively flat for the second half as we look at the order prospects that are coming in. Our margins had been exceptionally good, obviously, since that peak in Q2 of last year. And our mix is starting to shift from RAID to a little bit more of mix of our bright stars for the U.S. market. We have some cost reductions planned for the second half of this year. Hopefully, we'll get those engaged and be able to pull our margins at these higher levels. But I don't expect or anticipate a large shift in operating margin in the second half of this year.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, let me comment just for a second. When Andy talks about his margins being slightly less because there's more of Bill's product flowing through, that actually produces a higher margin at the corporate level effectively. So didn't want you to get the
componenttext: Paul, let me comment just for a second. When Andy talks about his margins being slightly less because there's more of Bill's product flowing through, that actually produces a higher margin at the corporate level effectively. So didn't want you to get the wrong impression on that answer. And secondly, we made the decision knowing full well that our revenue is going to be more difficult this year, late last year and early this year to expand our international operations. And so that's where you're seeing the cost come up in those side. But you also should see the revenue come up.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And the other question is you probably hear all these, for those of us here unfamiliar with Raymarine, can you just help us a little bit understand what the addressable market is and what segments of the marine market you're really going after here. Is it
componenttext: And the other question is you probably hear all these, for those of us here unfamiliar with Raymarine, can you just help us a little bit understand what the addressable market is and what segments of the marine market you're really going after here. Is it the ledger or is it some other segment that we should be aware of?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Raymarine's existing business for the most part, Paul, has been in the leisure side, if you will. Or leisure, as we'd say if I was home. That's been their business. Now we believe that we have an entre as a result of sort of certain of our, what you cal
componenttext: Raymarine's existing business for the most part, Paul, has been in the leisure side, if you will. Or leisure, as we'd say if I was home. That's been their business. Now we believe that we have an entre as a result of sort of certain of our, what you call, high-end government sales into the boating market to move some of their price up into that market. Typically, FURUNO is dominated more of the commercial side, and Raymarine's been more in the leisure side, if you will. But we see an opportunity to expand our business up a little bit, if you will, into the larger ships.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Any addressable market?
componenttext: Any addressable market?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The size? The addressable market, okay. That's a tough one because it just absolutely went to nothing two years ago. I mean, with that ...
componenttext: The size? The addressable market, okay. That's a tough one because it just absolutely went to nothing two years ago. I mean, with that ...

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things, Paul. I mean, there are some reports that have been done on the industry that Marine Electronics business itself is tagged at about $1.8 billion. There's roughly 100,000 GPS units, multi-function GPS in-dash units that are sold annuall
componenttext: A couple of things, Paul. I mean, there are some reports that have been done on the industry that Marine Electronics business itself is tagged at about $1.8 billion. There's roughly 100,000 GPS units, multi-function GPS in-dash units that are sold annually. So you can sort of look at, take rates off of those kinds of numbers that we think Thermal has a decent chance of penetrating.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, what Andy said is that using this new acquisition, we think we'll be able to significantly increase the thermal side of it. You're asking about the existing market, which is something we plan to penetrate some more as well. But that would be new mark
componenttext: Yes, what Andy said is that using this new acquisition, we think we'll be able to significantly increase the thermal side of it. You're asking about the existing market, which is something we plan to penetrate some more as well. But that would be new market.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jim Ricchiuti of Needham & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jim Ricchiuti of Needham & Company.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Question on the Thermography business, it sounds like you continue to see good growth in Asia Pacific. I wonder if you could talk a little bit more about that and just the business activity you're seeing in China, which is I guess emerging as a pretty goo
componenttext: Question on the Thermography business, it sounds like you continue to see good growth in Asia Pacific. I wonder if you could talk a little bit more about that and just the business activity you're seeing in China, which is I guess emerging as a pretty good market for you?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Jim, in Asia, China is now our number one market in Asia, and it's actually the number two market compared to the U.S. for Thermography worldwide. And we've made quite a strong investment in China and have a large number of sales offices and employe
componenttext: Well, Jim, in Asia, China is now our number one market in Asia, and it's actually the number two market compared to the U.S. for Thermography worldwide. And we've made quite a strong investment in China and have a large number of sales offices and employees there at present. The other market that also seems to be emerging fairly nicely in APAC region is Japan, and we've also opened up our own sales office and are hiring direct employees. We sell through distribution, but we have direct employees to manage them in the Japanese market. And then the third is Korea, and we bought out our distributor in Korea. I guess it was 18 months ago or so. And that's been a very good acquisition for FLIR, and it's turned out quite well. So those are the three strong points in APAC region right now.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: So you see that as pretty much sustainable, Andy?
componenttext: So you see that as pretty much sustainable, Andy?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: We do. I mean, the growth rates, double-digit growth rates, I think, are sustainable in the APAC region for some time to come. Earl mentioned also rightfully so that we have now planted flag in India, and we'll be opening three or four regional offices in
componenttext: We do. I mean, the growth rates, double-digit growth rates, I think, are sustainable in the APAC region for some time to come. Earl mentioned also rightfully so that we have now planted flag in India, and we'll be opening three or four regional offices in India over the course of 2010 and early 2011.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And just putting aside Germany for a second, as we think about the concerns people have on the macro side, I wonder if you'd comment on your expectations for the U.S. market in the second half of the year?
componenttext: And just putting aside Germany for a second, as we think about the concerns people have on the macro side, I wonder if you'd comment on your expectations for the U.S. market in the second half of the year?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, my expectation is that it's going to continue to grow. It sort of had high single-digit growth rates in the first half of the year, and my expectation is to push those into low double-digit growth rates in the second half of the year. I'm just not -
componenttext:
Well, my expectation is that it's going to continue to grow. It sort of had high single-digit growth rates in the first half of the year, and my expectation is to push those into low double-digit growth rates in the second half of the year. I'm just not -- we need a good economy to do that. The economy has got to get out of the sort of wait-and-see period and get back into a buying mode to have that happen.
I was just going to comment to Jim that it's still pretty soft in the upper end of the U.S. market. It seems like the capital spending rebound really hasn't quite gotten to where we'd like to see it yet.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Josephine Millward of the Benchmark Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Josephine Millward of the Benchmark Company.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: This is a question for Bill and Andy. My understanding is Customs and Border Protection is in the process of evaluating a mobile surveillance solution. Can you talk about your competitive positioning and when we might see a contract award?
componenttext: This is a question for Bill and Andy. My understanding is Customs and Border Protection is in the process of evaluating a mobile surveillance solution. Can you talk about your competitive positioning and when we might see a contract award?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: MSS, the program that we're certainly bidding sensors into, but not the complete solution. So I think it could happen this quarter, an award could happen. Do you have any more foresight into that?
componenttext: MSS, the program that we're certainly bidding sensors into, but not the complete solution. So I think it could happen this quarter, an award could happen. Do you have any more foresight into that?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, if you were asking a little bit about the competitive, how we feel about our competitive position, and the equipment that we sell into that application, Josephine, is the same equipment that we sell into border applications globally. And we com
componenttext: Well, yes, if you were asking a little bit about the competitive, how we feel about our competitive position, and the equipment that we sell into that application, Josephine, is the same equipment that we sell into border applications globally. And we compete quite favorably there. I think that when our sensors get put up against our competitors' sensors out on the border and they look for targets of distance, we tend to win those competitions. And last year, around this time, we released the system we call the HRC-X, which we think has the highest focal length, largest magnification in the business and it's a continuous zoom system, which most of the competitor systems are not, their discrete field of view system. So we think we compete very favorably there, and I think that if the competition is done on fair and objective basis that we'll do well.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you help us quantify this opportunity?
componenttext: Can you help us quantify this opportunity?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry.
componenttext: Sorry.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Is that a no?
componenttext: Is that a no?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a no.
componenttext: That's a no.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And this is a question for you, Bill. It's starting to look like this fiscal year '11 defense budget could be delayed beyond September. So if that happens, how do you think this might impact your outlook for defense in the second half of next year? Can yo
componenttext: And this is a question for you, Bill. It's starting to look like this fiscal year '11 defense budget could be delayed beyond September. So if that happens, how do you think this might impact your outlook for defense in the second half of next year? Can you just talk about that?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: All of the delayed supplemental, we've been struggling along and doing pretty good. I just think we're going to see a shift here in what we expected. Supplementals needs to be improved or else we have a continuing resolution and then the 2011 budget will
componenttext: All of the delayed supplemental, we've been struggling along and doing pretty good. I just think we're going to see a shift here in what we expected. Supplementals needs to be improved or else we have a continuing resolution and then the 2011 budget will happen last. I think we're just having a big right shift in spending. I still anticipate the spending to be rather conservative going into the next year. So we'll see what the impact is, and we still think that ISR and night vision products are the main part of the budget.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Michael French with Morgan Joseph.
componenttext: The next question comes from Michael French with Morgan Joseph.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: I have another follow-up on the budget for Bill. Given the delay in the supplemental, is it possible that Pentagon could dip into the procurement budget to fund operations? And if so, does that pose any risk to you?
componenttext: I have another follow-up on the budget for Bill. Given the delay in the supplemental, is it possible that Pentagon could dip into the procurement budget to fund operations? And if so, does that pose any risk to you?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Possible that typically what we see is some kind of a continuing resolution to take care of the basic needs. And that delays some procurements. But we're not wholly bound to that. I think we'll still see the money flow eventually and still get pieces and
componenttext: Possible that typically what we see is some kind of a continuing resolution to take care of the basic needs. And that delays some procurements. But we're not wholly bound to that. I think we'll still see the money flow eventually and still get pieces and parts of what's necessary for reset off of the supplemental. And I don't think they're going to dip too much into the procurement budget. Obviously, that happened in the past two months, so I think it's just a big right shift of when this is going to happen.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: And on this new program of record, when do you expect to start seeing more data from them in terms of the specs?
componenttext: And on this new program of record, when do you expect to start seeing more data from them in terms of the specs?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in order for them to make a program of record for 2012, they're going to have to start here sometime in the second half and try and conclude it in the first half of next year before it's written in. So they should be doing some more things the secon
componenttext: Well, in order for them to make a program of record for 2012, they're going to have to start here sometime in the second half and try and conclude it in the first half of next year before it's written in. So they should be doing some more things the second half of this year. We'll get better resolution into the specs the second half of this year.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, with that, operator, thank you all very much for tuning in. Appreciate it, and look forward to telling you how we did in the next quarter. As of right now, we're feeling pretty good about. So look forward to talking to you. Bye.
componenttext: Okay, with that, operator, thank you all very much for tuning in. Appreciate it, and look forward to telling you how we did in the next quarter. As of right now, we're feeling pretty good about. So look forward to talking to you. Bye.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-22-2010

componenttext: Thank you. This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Latika, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Third Quarter 2010 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Wit Davis, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Latika, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Third Quarter 2010 Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Wit Davis, you may begin your conference.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Before we begin this conference call, I need to remind you that other than statements as to historical facts, statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litig
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Before we begin this conference call, I need to remind you that other than statements as to historical facts, statements made on this conference call are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and are based on our current expectations. Words such as expects, anticipates, intends, believes, estimates and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify such forward-looking statements.
All of these statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to the press release we issued earlier today for a description of factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those forecast. The forward-looking statements we make today speak as of today, and we do not undertake any obligation to update any such statements to reflect events or circumstances occurring after today.
Let me now turn the call over to Earl Lewis, Chairman and CEO of FLIR Systems. Earl?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Wit. Good morning, everyone, and thank you all for joining us today. We had a successful third quarter with earnings of $0.39 per share on a 16% increase in revenue. Our Commercial Vision Systems revenue was up 17% over the third quarter
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Wit. Good morning, everyone, and thank you all for joining us today. We had a successful third quarter with earnings of $0.39 per share on a 16% increase in revenue. Our Commercial Vision Systems revenue was up 17% over the third quarter of 2009 to $61 million, and the division posted a 54% increase in their operating income.
Thermography revenue increased 4%, excluding the Extech printer division, which was sold in the fourth quarter of 2009 and generated 19% growth in operating income. While Government System revenue was essentially flat, operating margins remain robust at 38%. Our order activity for Government Systems were strong, backlog increased by approximately $10 million. 
During the first week of the fourth quarter, we closed the acquisition of ICx Technologies. We purchased the company for $232 million, net of their closing cash balance. This business was attractive for its technology leadership in chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear and explosive detection. It expands our footprint by adding products in these emerging detection sensor categories.
ICx also augments our surveillance capabilities by adding integration services and advanced radars to our portfolio. We believe there's significant opportunity to reduce costs, increase profitability by leveraging the FLIR operating model and focusing on the strength of ICx products and employees.
This quarter again demonstrates our ability to produce strong, profitable results. We have never felt better about our mix of products, diversity of our markets, our ability to innovate and our operational and financial flexibility. I'm now going to turn the call over to Tom Surran, who's filling in for Andy Teich, while he attends the advanced management program at Harvard. Both Tony and Bill are scheduled to attend this program next year. Tom will discuss the results in the Commercial Systems division. Tom?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Earl. Commercial Systems revenue, excluding Raymarine, was $132 million, up 8% over the third quarter results for CVS and Thermography last year. Operating income, again excluding Raymarine, increased 33% over the prior year to $40 million. Thermo
componenttext:
Thanks, Earl. Commercial Systems revenue, excluding Raymarine, was $132 million, up 8% over the third quarter results for CVS and Thermography last year. Operating income, again excluding Raymarine, increased 33% over the prior year to $40 million. Thermography revenue was $71 million, an increase of 4% over the third quarter of 2009 when you exclude that divested Extech printer division revenue from the third quarter of 2009.
Profitability improved significantly with operating income reaching 31% of revenue or $21.8 million. This represents a 19% increase over the prior year and our best operating margin performance since 2007. Unit volumes were up approximately 30% overall, and they doubled for the high-volume i5, i7 series cameras. 
The U.S. showed significant improvement in the high-end P-Series and T-Series sales, and we are seeing significant growth in the sales of our gas finder product. The electrical, mechanical and building markets, which together make up over 50% of Thermography revenue were flat during the quarter, in part due to the EMEA region being down compared to the third quarter of the prior year. 
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we expect to see the usual seasonal increase in our Thermography business. We continue to innovate and expand the applications for our products, and margins should remain strong as we continue to control costs and utilize our Sonia [ph] manufacturing site.
For the Commercial Vision Systems business, we saw another excellent quarter. Revenues were up 17% over the prior year to $61.4 million. Operating income was $18.1 million, up 54%, and yielding an operating margin of 29%. Compared to the third quarter of 2009, CVS operating margin improved over 700 basis points due to a favorable product mix, higher volumes and lower costs. Additionally, CVS backlog increased 12% over the second quarter this year to $116 million.
Demand in security and surveillance was very strong. Our growing global dealer base is driving awareness of our technology. And as a result, we saw strong growth in the number of orders for security and surveillance products. Cores and Components bookings were also up, reflecting strong demand for our new uncooled tau cores from our OEM customers. We are also seeing robust orders internationally for camera cores made by the former Cedip operation in France. Interest in our new short wave infrared tau cameras has been strong as has the reception of our new color night vision cameras, which use EMCCD technology. 
We expect great things from these products in 2011 and beyond. Auto continues to perform very well with bookings up significantly over the prior year, driven by the inclusion of our products in certain Audi models. Our Maritime bookings increased 50%, with the mix shift towards higher ASP products.
We completed our first full quarter with Raymarine, and performance was good. Revenue was $36.9 million, in line with our expectations for the seasonally weakest quarter of the year after the summer's voting season. Operating income was $1 million, up significantly from a loss in the prior year. Gross margins increased, while we continue to reduce operating expenses, showing our operational improvement plans are beginning to bare fruit.
There is more opportunity for improvement, and we are excited to be launching the integrated Raymarine branded thermal cameras at this fall's maritime trade shows. Overall, we are pleased with the performance of Commercial Systems, and we expect a strong fourth quarter, particularly in CVS. Being more dependent on macroeconomic trends, Thermography is expected to see a more modest growth experience to sustain worldwide economic growth.
Now Bill will discuss the Government Systems division.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Government Systems revenue in the quarter was $163.2 million, unchanged from the third quarter of 2009. Operating income was $62.2 million or 38% of revenue. Order activity was good during the quarter and our 12-month backlog came in at $3
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Government Systems revenue in the quarter was $163.2 million, unchanged from the third quarter of 2009. Operating income was $62.2 million or 38% of revenue. Order activity was good during the quarter and our 12-month backlog came in at $386 million, up $10 million from the second quarter of this year.
Airborne systems as well as ground-based applications saw strong orders in Q3. Domestically, we saw better orders from the U.S. government as their fiscal year came to a close at the end of September. We received an $18.5 million order from a U.S. agency for onboard aircraft systems, as well as a $14.4 million order for BRITE Star IIs from the Navy, which showcases our ongoing success with the Marine Corp NTIS program. 
Force protection initiative continue to show strength as we received a $5.3 million order for our Star SAFIRE HD gimbal system. Additionally, we were awarded $63 million IDIQ from the U.S. Army for spares for the RAID program. While no new RAID system orders are expected in the near future, we continue to provide service and spares that deal with systems.
Our international business continues to grow as we were awarded a $4.1 million contract from a European helicopter manufacturer. We continued our penetration at the soldier level with the $2.1 million order to a European agency for weapon scopes. Investments in sales and service operations around the world are growing our footprint into key emerging markets, such as in Northern Africa, India and Russia.
Additionally, we had an official opening in Q3 of our new operation center in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia in order to increase our service capacity in the region. Overall, we are seeing our efforts to expand our troop level and other ground-based exposure to exceed as we received over $30 million in orders for our recon handheld products during the quarter.
Our Boston location had its best booking quarter ever, suggesting particular strength in smaller gimbals and handheld products that incorporate latest feature sets into smaller, lighter systems.
Excluding ICx, our revenue and profit outlook for all of 2010 has not changed. We currently anticipate a challenging environment for fourth quarter bookings, as we navigate a difficult spending environment, especially in the U.S. Over the longer term, we see significant opportunity as users recognize the merits of innovations, such as digital high-definition systems, and the market evolves from analog to HD.
The close of the ICx acquisition is an exciting event for Government Systems and for FLIR. The inclusion of their products and platforms will allow us to expand our leadership in force protection and government agencies around the world with everything from thermal sensor systems and radars to explosive detectors and integrated systems. We continue to work on the integration of the business into our division. ICx's solid IP portfolio, dedicated employees and culture of innovation will indeed be a solid fit wit FLIR, and we expect excellent opportunity for sustained growth. 
I'll turn the call back over to Earl.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. The FLIR operating model continues to succeed as shown by these third quarter results. We continue to penetrate our infrared markets. Our customer base is growing, along with the applications and use of tools that we make in the field. We're
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. The FLIR operating model continues to succeed as shown by these third quarter results. We continue to penetrate our infrared markets. Our customer base is growing, along with the applications and use of tools that we make in the field. We're optimistically diversifying into areas of growth, exemplified by our two latest acquisitions, Raymarine providing us with adjacent markets, and ICx providing us with adjacent products. We are leveraged in our leadership in the industry to drive down cost and build awareness, which is working to grow the size of our addressable markets. These strategies have not changed and we continue to execute on these goals.
Our challenge as we ended the last quarter of the year is to gain more clarity in how the changing dynamics of the U.S. military spending will impact our overall Government Systems business. I'm encouraged with the growth of Government Systems as shown in the face of this macro environment. Our U.S. military revenue represents less than 25% of our total revenue. And while we continue to see significant opportunity in this important market, we are very pleased with the diversification we have, not only within GS but across the company.
Commercial Systems continues to grow rapidly by executing on the vision of infrared everywhere, and has successfully improved profitability along the way. Thermography is a leader in smart goods, and we see renewed growth ahead. Our two acquisitions will add meaningfully to our growth in the years ahead. Our balance sheet remains strong. It provides us with sustainable substantial flexibility in 2011.
Our guidance for 2010 is improved based on the outlook for Q4 and the impact of our acquisitions. We now estimate our full year earnings per share will be in the range of $1.53 to $1.56. We are increasing our revenue outlook range for the year to $1.375 billion to $1.4 billion to reflect the addition of ICx. Including the costs associated with acquisitions, we expect both ICx and Raymarine to be profitable in Q4 2010 and substantially accretive in 2011 and beyond.
Now Tony will go through a detailed review of our financials.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Earl. Third quarter revenue increased 16% overall, and 4% excluding Raymarine. Revenue growth in constant currency terms without Raymarine was 5%. Commercial Vision Systems revenue increased 17%, with particularly good growth in transportation, co
componenttext:
Thanks, Earl. Third quarter revenue increased 16% overall, and 4% excluding Raymarine. Revenue growth in constant currency terms without Raymarine was 5%. Commercial Vision Systems revenue increased 17%, with particularly good growth in transportation, cores and personal vision systems market. 
Thermography sales increased 2% during the quarter, or 4% when excluding Extech's printer division revenues for Q3 2009, aided by better demand in the U.S. for gas imaging products and strength in test and measurement markets.
Government Systems revenue was unchanged from the third quarter of 2009. International revenue was 32.9% of the total in Government Systems. And for the entire company, international revenue was 41.9% of the total compared with 43.5% in the third quarter of 2009.
Sales to the U.S. government represent a 35.9% of total revenue in Q3, down from 43.8% of revenue in the third quarter of last year. Consolidated gross margin was 54.8% for the quarter. Excluding Raymarine, gross margin in Q3 was 57.1% compared with 57% in the third quarter of 2009.
Consolidated operating margin in the third quarter was 25.8%, and 28.7% excluding Raymarine. This compares with an operating margin of 31.3% last Q3.
Government Systems operating income for the quarter was $62.2 million compared with $71.8 million in the third quarter last year. GS operating margins remained robust at 38.1% versus the near record level of 44.1% in Q3 of 2009.
Thermography operating income increased by 19% to $21.8 million, yielding an operating margin of 30.7%, up 4.6 percentage points over Q3 2009 and the highest Thermography operating margins since 2007.
Commercial Vision Systems earned an operating income of $18.1 million in Q3, up 54% last year, while CVS operating margin increased by 7.1 percentage points to 29.4%.
Corporate expenses in the third quarter were $17.2 million, an increase of $4.8 million from last year. Included in the Q3 corporate expenses was $2.5 million of costs associated with the ICx acquisition and an accrual of $3 million related to an agreement in principal to settle all pending tax claims associated with the litigation matter dating back to 2007.
Excluding these items, corporate expenses were down 6% compared to Q3 2009. Raymarine reported third quarter revenue of $36.9 million and operating income of $1 million. We substantially completed the purchase price allocation for Raymarine during the quarter, and included in the Q3 results was approximately $1.2 million in amortization of intangible assets.
Going forward, intangible amortization at Raymarine will be approximately $900,000 per quarter. Raymarine made good progress in reducing run rate expense and streamline of supply chain during the quarter, and we expect further improvement in these areas moving forward. Q4 is a seasonally slow period in the marine electronics business, but we do expect Raymarine to be profitable in Q4.
Other income for the quarter totaled $1.1 million, a swing of $2.7 million from Q3 of 2009. The majority of other income related to a currency gain of $606,000 as compared to the currency loss of $3 million in Q3 2009.
Our tax rate for the quarter was 27.2% compared with 30.5% in Q3 2009. This year's third quarter tax expense was favorably impacted by the release of tax reserves, driven by the expiration of certain statutory periods in the U.S., partly offset by the capitalization for tax purposes of $2.5 million in expenses associated with the ICx acquisition.
In total, nonrecurring expenses related to the ICx acquisition and the legal reserve were largely offset by our lower tax rate. Cash flow from operations for the quarter was very strong at $85.1 million compared to $67.4 million last Q3. Investments for the quarter were modest, with 99,000 shares of stocks repurchased for a total of $2.4 million and $7.2 million in capital expenditures.  As a result, cash on hand increased by $95.4 million to $380 million.
Moving to the balance sheet. The largest shift during the quarter was due to the substantial completion of the purchase price allocation for Raymarine, which reallocated $128 million from other assets equally to goodwill and intangible assets. One item still to be completed is the allocation of certain tax assets associated with Raymarine which will be concluded in Q4.
We completed the previously announced acquisition of ICx Technologies on October 4 for a total of $232 million, net of $36 million in cash acquired. In Q4, we will complete the purchase price allocation for ICx, and currently estimate amortization of intangible to be in the range of $2 million to $3 million in Q4. In addition, we anticipate additional transaction expenses of approximately $2 million to $3 million during the quarter.
Including all of these items, we do expect ICx to be profitable in the fourth quarter. Including all of these items, we now anticipate earnings per share for all of 2010 to be in the range of $1.53 to $1.56 compared with our previous full year EPS outlook of $1.48 to $1.53. Our full year revenue outlook including ICx and Raymarine is now $1.375 billion to $1.4 billion.
This concludes the summary of our third quarter financial results. Let me now turn the call back to Earl.

componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, yes, absolutely there is a region. Our European revenue was not what we expected this quarter. And our U.S. was way ahead of what we expected and so is the Far East. And we continue to have issues in Europe. And some of those are management
componenttext: Well, I guess, yes, absolutely there is a region. Our European revenue was not what we expected this quarter. And our U.S. was way ahead of what we expected and so is the Far East. And we continue to have issues in Europe. And some of those are management internally. We're in the process of restructuring Europe, and we're still doing that. And I think once that's completed, which I believe should be this quarter, we'll see that improve.

componenttext: Maybe let me answer that differently. We, right now, have two pretty good-sized acquisitions, one in each of the divisions that we've got to manage. And so we feel that those businesses are up and running and as profitable as we think they should be. We're probably not going to be buying any large companies right now. And our stock is clearly attractive. So that's the way, I guess, I would suggest, at least in the next couple of quarters, we might allocate our capital.

componenttext: We certainly hope so. There's a potential of a ruling that will come this quarter. And some of, I think, the buying that we've seen is due to people participating in that ruling that we'll select essentially the Gas Finder product line for EPA measurement of both, I think. I'm not sure which gases they're specifying in this, but there is a potential ruling that should help us in that area. And I think we've seen some anticipation of -- we're also seeing European demand increasing after the Gas Finder.

But reflected in the guidance is the expectation that you'll have a pretty strong shipping quarter, revenue quarter, in the fourth quarter, but bookings might be impacted by the timing of budgets. And when do you see -- I mean, I know the crystal ball is cloudy, but when do you see the potential for bookings to improve in the Government business?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Tim, the continuing resolution is going on until December 3. And we're anticipating the defense budget to be released, hopefully, in that kind of timeframe. There are definitely things that are in that budget that are headed our way that should help
componenttext: Well, Tim, the continuing resolution is going on until December 3. And we're anticipating the defense budget to be released, hopefully, in that kind of timeframe. There are definitely things that are in that budget that are headed our way that should help improve things. So I've been fairly impressed with Q3's bookings. It's not where we thought it was going to be. And Q4 will give us what we need to build very strong. I want to say that even though in Q3, our revenue was flat. Q3 of last year, however, $30 million of great shipments in it and this quarter was less than $3 million of RAID shipments in Q3. And Q4, we'll have very few. So we're getting other opportunities to grow in that pipeline. But to really kind of anticipate in the new year as we start to see a resurgence ones the defense budget gets back on track and some of the other opportunities that we're chasing continue to be pushed to the right. So I'm hoping that in the new year, we'll start to see a pickup.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Or future multiple. We'll be an IR company. These two acquisitions, both are based, as I mentioned in my script, on their ability to add to IR, our ability to use them to increase IR. So IR is going to be the heart of this company. I don't see that changi
componenttext: Or future multiple. We'll be an IR company. These two acquisitions, both are based, as I mentioned in my script, on their ability to add to IR, our ability to use them to increase IR. So IR is going to be the heart of this company. I don't see that changing. The issue is that we -- packing on $10 million acquisitions is probably not so good either. Having the multiple sensors driven by IR, we believe, is a good strategy. So I don't see us ever really not being an IR company. Those markets are just too big, too high growth for us to ever abandon. Adding on products, adding on markets, I think, is a valid thing in a relatively slow period, which is what we've been going through the last couple of years.

componenttextpreview: Yes, so we've introduced what we're calling the T-Series products to the maritime markets through Raymarine. We're introducing that integrated into the MFDs, so that through, say, the, what we call the E-series product, Raymarine's MFD, you have touch con
componenttext: Yes, so we've introduced what we're calling the T-Series products to the maritime markets through Raymarine. We're introducing that integrated into the MFDs, so that through, say, the, what we call the E-series product, Raymarine's MFD, you have touch control of that imager. The response by the market has been exceptionally strong. We've bought that out to some of the boat shows that are occurring now and will be occurring to the winter. And everyone who sees the product loves the integration. They understand the value to the boater and how that will increase their usability of the boats.

componenttext: I think we've actually booked a couple of orders that we might not have gotten without the integration of infrared into a Raymarine suite of products.

componenttext: You are already seeing that?

componenttext: It is coming to it. It's actually being a differentiator to us in the market place. And there was a specific order that would occur for a safety organization where the ability to have the integration of the night vision into the suite of electronics was the basically key deciding factor in selecting Raymarine products.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: There's an awful lot of "wild" factor in this. And people do really like it. The fact that it's integrated now with the radars, with the GPSs, with the Depth Sounders, et cetera, means it's really very much a part of a voter's experience. And I see this as a  -- just right now, we're starting to demo that. And It's been very favorably received by the press and by people who've seen it.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Ricchiuti from Needham & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Ricchiuti from Needham & Company.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on the ICx acquisition, Earl. In the past, the company has struggled with getting the profitability. They've been investing quite a bit in the business, and you expect the business to be profitable in Q4. And I wonder, how much of that is just th
componenttext: Question on the ICx acquisition, Earl. In the past, the company has struggled with getting the profitability. They've been investing quite a bit in the business, and you expect the business to be profitable in Q4. And I wonder, how much of that is just the elimination of the public company expense? Or have you already begun to streamline the business and consolidate a little bit of the operations?

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a multi-headed answer, unfortunately, Jim. Yes, of course, we'll save some of the money as a result of not being a public company anymore. The other thing is Q4 is traditionally, I think, pretty good for them. And so they all have pretty good reven
componenttext: That's a multi-headed answer, unfortunately, Jim. Yes, of course, we'll save some of the money as a result of not being a public company anymore. The other thing is Q4 is traditionally, I think, pretty good for them. And so they all have pretty good revenue in Q4. I think the real issue of pointing that here is they historically have had not been very good at forecasting their profitability of meeting their numbers that they have. And I think one of the big reasons for that is that it is a company that is very much decentralized. It has multiple locations. I think it's more like 30 locations around the U.S. and some in Canada and Europe. And it's been relatively tough to manage. It has not been well integrated. And I don't mean that negatively to previous management. I just think that there is some integration that needs to be done. And I think there's some trimming that needs to be done. And that will be a process that we are beginning. I think the people at ICx are excited about the opportunity to join FLIR. They can see where our products and their products can add value to the customer together, particularly when we integrate them together. So I think there's a lot of work to be done, clearly. But I think the people at ICx are up to it. I think we're up to it, and we have begun.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you expect to have this integration fully complete by the second half, or at the end of the first half of next year? And I wonder if you could also can comment on the backlog for ICx.
componenttext: Do you expect to have this integration fully complete by the second half, or at the end of the first half of next year? And I wonder if you could also can comment on the backlog for ICx.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Jim. I don't have that number. I should have it right now, but I actually don't. It would surprise me to be $50 million, $60 million, $70 million, somewhere in there. But I actually don't have it. I've been kind of asking for it, b
componenttext: That's a good question, Jim. I don't have that number. I should have it right now, but I actually don't. It would surprise me to be $50 million, $60 million, $70 million, somewhere in there. But I actually don't have it. I've been kind of asking for it, but don't have it yet. Integration should be done, I'd say, middle of next year. I think we should be complete. We'll try to get it done sooner than that. But as you know, we already have the plan. We're not waiting on the plan anymore. Bill's done a great job pulling that together and going in meeting with all the people at ICx. So I think the plan is there. We know what we want to do. We want to have some meetings before the end of this year with the different ICx managers to get their input on how they want to run their business next year, and then we'll start implementing probably early next year. And there's no reason why we shouldn't be done by the end of the second quarter.

headline: FLIR Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I think it's more like the latter number, but we don't have a handle on it yet completely. We know that they should have a good Q4. They've indicated that there's some pluses and minuses, and going into making the sausage probably isn't good here. But we think it should be a fairly good quarter in that range you mentioned.

componenttext: So roughly $60 million?

componenttext: Yes, the question, of course, Josephine, is what does roughly mean? And if you want to accept $60 million with a roughly, that's what I put on the table now.
